INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Georgia 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsectors): Transport, and information and 
communication technology (road transport, transport management 
and policies) 
Themes (subthemes): Regional cooperation (cross-border 
infrastructure, trade and investment); economic growth (promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling business environment, widening 
access to markets and economic opportunities); private sector 
development (public–private partnerships); capacity development 
(institutional development) 
Location impact: Regional (high impact), national (high impact), 
urban (medium impact), rural (medium impact)  
Partnership(s): Japan International Cooperation Agency, 
Millennium Challenge Corporation, World Bank 
   
Investment Program  The Caucasus subregion is a land bridge between the Black and 
Description  Caspian seas. It is the shortest transit link to connect Central Asia 
to Europe, the Russian Federation, and Turkey. The subregion 
once served caravans from the People’s Republic of China to the 
West along the historic Silk Road, but is now a conduit for oil and 
other exports from Central Asia and the Caucasus. Yet, despite 
the substantial transit potential, opportunities for this are affected 
by  the  degraded  state  of  basic  transport  infrastructure  and 
logistics services.  
 
The  east–west  highway  between  Azerbaijan  and  Georgia  is 
already a major route for oil exports from Azerbaijan and Central 
Asian countries, in both cases relying on the ports of Poti and 
Batumi on the Black Sea as the exit points.  Another corridor 
further south also uses these ports, but this time it services trade 
flows to and from Armenia.  This second corridor links the Agrak–
Kapan–Yerevan–Bavra  road  in  Armenia  with  two  southern 
sections in Georgia.  
 
This transit potential is recognized by all countries in the region 
and further afield and is now the subject of major investment 
programs to improve road infrastructure, related transport services 
and the institutions responsible for them. The Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  and  other  development  partners  have  been 
requested  by  three  countries  in  the  region  to  cofinance  such 
investments.  ADB has already started doing so in Azerbaijan 
through a multitranche financing facility (MFF) approved in 2008. 
Armenia and Georgia are now requesting similar support through 
the same modality. Although separate legal transactions, the three 
operations are to all in intents and purposes part of an integrated 
road corridor development program.  This proposal targets the 
investments in Georgia.

In  2008,  the  Government  of  Georgia  endorsed  a  joint  needs 
assessment (JNA) prepared by the United Nations together with  
ADB,  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development, 
European Commission, European Investment Bank, International 
Finance  Corporation,  and  the  World  Bank.  The  JNA 
recommended investments in the country's road networks, noting 
its poor state of repair and the negative impact on the cost of 
doing  business  and  foreign  direct  investment.    The  JNA  also 
emphasized  the  need  for  subregional  multi-road  corridors  to 
provide more secure and effective transit routes to neighboring 
countries.  In 2009, the Roads Department under the Ministry of 
Regional  Development  and  Infrastructure  updated  the  road 
transport  infrastructure  investment  plan,  identifying  1,842 
kilometers (km)—372 km of main roads, 470 km of alternative 
roads, and 1,000 km of secondary and local roads—in need of 
urgent modernization, upgrading, expansion and/or rehabilitation. 
The investment program also included non-physical components 
such  as  (i)  better  sector  policy  and  operating  procedures;  (ii) 
private sector participation in construction and maintenance; and 
(iii)  the  development  of  capacity  to  improve  planning,  project 
management, monitoring, evaluation, and reporting. The overall 
investment plan is estimated at $3 billion over the next 7 years. 
This plan needs external financing. The Government has already 
approached  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  the  Millennium  Challenge 
Corporation, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency for 
assistance.  
 
  Tranche 1 of this investment program has four components: (i) the 
construction  of  a  34  km  two-lane  bypass  skirting  Kobuleti, 
(ii) capacity assistance to the Roads Department; (iii) road safety 
measures and (iv) project management support, including experts 
to work on detailed works design and contractor supervision. 
   
Multitranche Financing  The Government requested ADB to extend up to $500 million for 
Facility  the program through  an MFF. This financing will blend ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources (OCR) and Special Funds resources, 
depending on availability. The MFF will be structured into several 
loans to be disbursed on the basis of periodic financing requests 
(PFRs),  related  loan  agreements  and  various  warranties  and 
representations. The MFF modality offers greater flexibility than 
other modalities, frontloads the analytical work and leaves for time 
and resources for implementation and reforms.  The modality links 
project  readiness  to  investment  financing  and  combines  road 
construction work with institutional effectiveness. It adds certainty 
to  the  financing  plan  while  paving  the  way  for  long  term 
partnerships with the government and other cofinanciers.  Stand-
alone project loans, traditional program lending, sector lending 
and/or development program loans are less suitable modalities in 
this instance.  Georgia meets all the conditions needed for the use 
of an MFF. It has sound road map for the sector, a strong policy

iii
framework, a clear investment plan and a tentative financing plan. 
 
The Government will enter into a framework financing agreement 
(FFA) with ADB for the purposes of the program. The first PFR for 
tranche  1  amounts  to  about  $120  million  from  ADB’s  Special 
Funds resources. The first PFR is being presented to the ADB 
Board of Directors together with this report and the FFA. 
   
Rationale  Connectivity,  both  domestic  and  international,  is  the  key  to 
sustainable development in Georgia. However, rapid growth in 
traffic up to 2008 and lack of investment since independence have 
greatly  diminished  the  efficiency  of  the  subregional  corridors. 
Growth  and  poverty  reduction  have  stalled,  as  a  result.  The 
corridors must increase their capacity, through new investment 
and  better  maintenance.  Improved  road  safety  measures  and 
standards, and “soft” investments to facilitate cross-border trade 
and transit traffic, are also needed. 
 
The  Roads  Department  spent  an  average  of  GEL199  million 
yearly  in  2004–2008.  In  2009  it  expects  to  spend 
GEL521 million—44% for new construction, 51% for rehabilitation, 
and 5% for routine maintenance. Expenditure is expected to reach 
GEL1  billion  in  2010.  ADB,  JICA,  the  Millennium  Challenge 
Corporation, and the World Bank will finance part of Investment 
Program. As roads are a strategically important part of ADB’s 
interim operational strategy 2008–2009 for Georgia, and ADB was 
an active participant in the JNA, the investment program deserves 
ADB’s support. The MFF modality will keep ADB committed over 
the  long  term  to  the  Government’s  implementation  of  the 
Investment  Program.  It  will  (i) give  the  Government  greater 
certainty  in  financing,  and  (ii) allow  it  to  borrow  according  to 
progress in project preparation. The MFF will also help create a 
long-term partnership between ADB and Georgia. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Investment Program will promote economic development and 
subregional  trade,  and  accelerate  subregional  cooperation  and 
integration. It will create better trade corridors, and thus facilitate 
the cross-border movement of people and cargo. The outcome 
will  be  an  improved  subregional  road  network.  Successful 
implementation  of  the  Investment  Program  will  (i)  improve  the 
efficiency of subregional road traffic through Georgia; (ii) increase 
trade  flows  and  competitiveness;  (iii) lower  transport  costs; 
(iv) increase mobility and accessibility to markets, jobs, and social 
services; and (v) improve governance.  
   
Investment Plan  The  investment  program  will  cost  about  $3  billion.  Project  1, 
amounts to about $150 million, including taxes, duties, physical 
and price contingencies, interest, and other charges.

MFF —Amount and  $500 million in the form of loans from OCR and Special Funds 
Terms  resources. OCR financing will conform to the Ordinary Operations 
Loan  Regulations,  subject  to  modifications  in  individual  loan 
agreements. Each OCR loan will carry an interest rate determined 
according to ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)–based 
lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year,  and 
other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  related  loan 
agreements. A loan from Special Funds resources will have a 
term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years, and interest 
of  1.0%  per  year  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  year 
thereafter, and other terms and conditions set forth in the related 
loan agreement. 
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June 2017 
   
Estimated Completion  31 December 2016 
Date 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Regional Development and Infrastructure (MORDI) 
   
Implementation  The implementing agency will be the Roads Department, assisted 
Arrangements  by the Eurasian Transport Corridor Investment Center (ETCIC). 
The Roads Department will supervise the investment program, 
and a foreign projects unit (FPU) within the department will handle 
all implementation activities. The FPU will comprise technical staff 
from the Roads Department and external experts (national and 
international). Financial management activities will be outsourced 
to ETCIC. The FPU will also (i) prepare new PFRs, (ii) manage 
the work of supervision consultants and contractors, (iii) prepare 
performance  reports  for  the  Government,  ADB  and  other  co-
financiers  and  (iv)  obtain  approvals  from  ADB  and  the 
Government  on  new  funding.  The  team  will  also  manage 
procurement, safeguards compliance, financial and legal matters, 
contract  variation  proposals,  and  nonphysical  investment 
components, including an institutional effectiveness program.  
   
Procurement  Procurement  will  comply  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Contracts above $1 million 
for  civil  works  and  above  $500,000  for  goods  will  undergo 
international competitive bidding. National competitive bidding, for 
contracts  below  those  amounts,  will  be  conducted  under 
Georgia’s state procurement law, subject to the modifications and 
clarifications stated in the procurement plan. 
   
Consulting Services  Consulting services will be required for project management and 
capacity development and road safety. Key tasks are (i) feasibility 
studies  and  detailed  design  (ii)  contractor  engagement  and 
construction supervision (iii) project performance monitoring and 
reporting  and  results  measurement  (iv)  road  safety  training, 
amendment  of  road  safety  regulations,  and  development  of 
standards for intelligent traffic systems and (v) general capacity

development at the Roads Department. The Roads Department 
will select and hire the consultants according to ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants, using quality-based selection for the 
detailed design and supervision consultants and quality- and cost-
based  selection  (80:20  or  other  ratios,  as  appropriate)  for  the 
project  management,  capacity  development  and  road  safety 
improvement. Other selection modalities will also be considered.  
 
Tranche  1  investments  will  require  1,330  person-months  of 
consulting  services  (230 international  and  1,100  national).  This 
comprises  (i) 1,056  person-months  (164  international  and  892 
national) for the detailed design of projects 1 and 2, construction 
supervision,  and  project  monitoring,  evaluation  and  results 
measurement;  (ii)  31  person-months  (11 international  and  20 
national)  for  road  safety;  and  (iii) 243 person-months  (55 
international  and  188  national)  for  capacity  development. 
Additional  consulting  services,  if  necessary,  will  be  procured 
under funding under later tranches.  
 
Advance Contracting and  To speed up project implementation, starting with Tranche 1, the 
Retroactive Financing  Government requests ADB’s approval under the MFF for advance 
contracting  and  retroactive  financing  of  eligible  expenditures. 
Advance  contracting  will  allow  the  Government  to  start  the 
procurement  process  before  the  relevant  legal  agreement  is 
signed.  The  Government  was  informed  that  expenses  under 
advance  contracting  can  be  financed  retroactively  only  if  the 
procedures  (including  advertising)  comply  with 
ADB’s Procurement  Guidelines  and  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants.  Once  first  loan is in  place,  up to  20%  of  it  may 
retroactively finance eligible expenditures incurred no more than 
12 months before the signing of the relevant legal agreement. 
Alternatively,  the  Government  may  also  opt  for  advance 
contracting without retroactive financing. In that case, the contract 
for procurement procedures completed under advance contracting 
is  awarded  after  the  tranche  takes  effect.  The  Government 
acknowledges  that  ADB’s  concurrence  with  the  procedures, 
documentation, or proposal for award does not commit ADB to 
finance such expenses or the related project. 
   
Environment  An  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  for  the 
Assessment  Investment Program was prepared for the MFF. Tranche 1 of the 
MFF  is  a  category  A  project.  An  environmental  impact 
assessment (EIA) was prepared, and the summary EIA circulated 
to the Board and was publicly disclosed through the ADB website 
on 29 May 2009.  
   
Investment Program  The Investment Program will benefit road users, road construction 
Benefits and  companies, traders, logistics companies, and other people who 
Beneficiaries  derive income from increased road traffic and trade in Georgia. 
Regarding direct benefits, the improved road network will (i) lower 
road transport and maintenance costs, (ii) speed up road transport

vii
services and make them more reliable, (iii) reduce travel time for 
cross-border  transit  traffic,  (iv)  reduce  traffic  accidents, 
(v) improve access to markets and social services, (vi) create jobs 
and income during implementation (through the use of local labor 
and  construction  materials)  and  after  completion  (through 
roadside  business  activities),  and  (vii) reduce  air  pollution  and 
noise in resort areas where the existing road passes. The direct 
benefits will initially accrue to vehicle owners and operators and 
road  construction  companies,  but  will  gradually  be  shared  by 
freight customers and passengers through reduced bus freight 
charges and fares. While Georgia is the major beneficiary, other 
countries in the region, particularly Armenia, Azerbaijan, Turkey 
and Central Asia, will also benefit from the modernization of the 
various subregional corridors. These investments will also open 
the way for an expansion and modernization of the ports of Poti 
and Batumi (most likely with private sector investors) and create 
cross-border and trade facilitation agreements in the region. The 
investment  program  will  also  (i)  improve  road  network 
management, and (ii) increase business activities and jobs with 
forward or backward linkages to road network development. 
 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  investment  program  rests  on  several  assumptions:  (i) 
continued  macroeconomic  stability  in  Georgia,  (ii)  effective 
implementation  of  the  JNA,  (iii) the  Government’s  continued 
commitment  to  regional  cooperation,  (iv) the  Government’s 
commitment to implementing the road map and the investment 
program, and (v) adequate financing. The program also needs 
investments  in  the  neighboring  countries  and  cross  border 
agreements to speed up document clearance and cut costs and 
travel time. 
 
Risks  to  the  investment  program  include  (i)  low  coordination 
among  government  agencies  during  implementation,  (ii)  rapid 
deterioration  of  the  road  network  caused  by  weak  axle-load 
controls and insufficient funding for maintenance, (iii) delays in the 
preparation  and  implementation  of  subsequent  projects,  and 
(iv) delays  in  the  start  of  project  implementation  caused  by 
inadequate  design  and  preconstruction  works.  The  investment 
program  needs  coordinated  investments  in  the  neighboring 
countries. The Government has taken the necessary measures to 
minimize  these  risks.  MORDI  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  will 
coordinate the work of the agencies so that execution issues are 
resolved  promptly.  The  Government  is  committed  to  enforcing 
axle-load  controls  and  further  increasing  funding  for  road 
maintenance.  ADB,  with  its  partners,  will  provide  sustained 
support to the Roads Department to strengthen its capacity to 
manage the road network. Adequate consulting services will be 
provided  to  help  the  Roads  Department  prepare  subsequent 
projects, manage implementation, monitor performance, measure 
results and report to ADB. With its own funds the Government has

begun  detailed  design  and  other  preconstruction  works  to  be 
ready  to  start  construction  once  the  investment  program  is 
approved by ADB. Other countries in the region are investing in 
their own sections of the corridors.  ADB is also a co-financier in 
these  cases.  Cross-border  and  trade  facilitation  work  is  being 
developed under the Central Asia Regional Cooperation Program 
(CAREC).  The  implementation  of  the  physical  infrastructure 
components will be accompanied with work to speed up border 
crossing and cut paperwork.  Technical assistance will be put in 
place for this purpose.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to Georgia for the Road Corridor Investment Program. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.   The Caucasus subregion is a land bridge between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. 
It is the shortest transit link to connect Central Asia to Europe, the Russian Federation, and 
Turkey. The subregion once served caravans from the People’s Republic of China to the West 
along the historic Silk Road, but is now a conduit for oil and other exports from Central Asia and 
the Caucasus. Yet, despite the substantial transit potential, opportunities for this are affected by 
the degraded state of basic transport infrastructure and logistics services.  
 
3.  The east–west highway between Azerbaijan and Georgia is already a major route for oil 
exports from Azerbaijan and Central Asian countries, in both cases relying on the ports of Poti 
and Batumi on the Black Sea as the exit points.  Another corridor further south also uses these 
ports, but this time it services trade flows to and from Armenia.  This second corridor links the 
Agrak–Kapan–Yerevan–Bavra road in Armenia with two southern sections in Georgia. 
1.  Road Infrastructure and Motor Fleet 
4.  The transport network in Georgia consists comprises roads, railways, ports, airports, and 
oil and gas pipelines. Road transport accounted for 89% of domestic passenger-kilometers 
(passenger-km)  and  8%  of  freight  ton-km  in  2008.  Transport  is  an  increasingly  significant 
economic sector, contributing about 615% more to gross domestic product (GDP) in 2007 
(GEL1,231 million) than in 1996 (GEL172 million). Goods moved by road have quadrupled in 
volume, from 131 million ton-km in 1996 to 586 million ton-km in 2006.  
 
5.  The road network comprises 20,329 km. There are 1,495 km of international roads (with 
cross-border links), 5,446 km of secondary roads (between major cities and regional centers) 
and  13,386 km  of  local  roads  (between  villages  and  regional  centers).  International  roads 
include the five major highways, totaling 859 km: (i) Poti–Tbilisi–Red Bridge, (ii) Mtskheta–
Kazbegi–Larsi, (iii) Sarpi–Batumi–Samtredia, (iv) Khashuri–Akhaltsikhe–Turkish border, and (v) 
Tbilisi–Marneuli–Guguti. The Poti–Tbilisi–Red Bridge highway runs east–west from the port of 
Poti on the Black Sea to the Azerbaijan border. The latter then effectively connects the country 
to the Caspian. The Sarpi–Batumi–Samtredia highway extends the east–west highway to the 
Turkish border along the Black Sea coast.  
 
6.  The road network was developed under the former Soviet Union. Insufficient funding for 
road maintenance since independence has led to a deterioration in the quality of the assets.  
About 24% of the secondary road network is under the Roads Department of the Ministry of 
Regional Development and Infrastructure (MORDI), and almost 90% of local roads. All but 
55 km of the 1,495 km of international roads are paved, but the pavement ratio is only 61% for 
secondary roads and an even lower 23% for local roads. National road density (both paved and 
unpaved roads) is 290 km per 1,000 square kilometers (km2). The poor condition of the roads

2   
has  made  them  less  safe  and  increased  transport  costs.  Rigid  technical  standards  and 
specifications for road design, construction, and maintenance, most dating back to the Soviet 
era, consider only traffic volume and not level of service or economic viability in road capacity 
upgrades—a  feature  shared  with  the  other  countries  in  the  region.  The  Government  has 
recognized  that  such  outdated  standards  are  not  suited  to  the  needs  of  a  market-based 
economy wishing to become a major transit center. As a result, it has now introduced new 
standards based on European benchmarks. 
 
7.  Registered  vehicles  numbered  601,000  in  2008—501,000  cars,  58,000  trucks,  and 
42,000 buses. The vehicle fleet grew rapidly, by 12% per annum, from 2000 to 2008. Vehicle 
ownership per 1,000 people increased from 56 in 2000 to 140 in 2008. The increase in vehicle 
ownership is attributed to recent high rates of economic growth and tariff reductions after 
Georgia joined the World Trade Organization in 1999. The fleet has also been modernized as 
Soviet  era  vehicles  have  been  replaced  by  Western,  Japanese  and  other  Asian  imports, 
improving  vehicle  safety  and  reducing  fuel  consumption  by  individual  vehicles  and  fuel 
emissions. 
2.  Road Transport Service 
8.  Georgia’s road freight industry is made up of private companies but is unregulated. Entry 
into the market is easy. The freight rates of GEL0.20–GEL0.27 per ton-km for hauls of 100–500 
km  come  with  highly  competitive  market  prices.  Intercity  bus  services  are  extensive  and 
frequent, and are deregulated with no official controls on prices. But fares between bus stations 
(e.g., between Tbilisi and Batumi) are influenced by bus station operators, who also manage 
capacity. A new entrant would find it difficult to operate a new service from an existing bus 
station. This unofficial control of both prices and capacity hinders the development of new 
services (e.g., express services). Bus fares are nonetheless competitive with rail passenger 
service rates. Rail passengers between Tbilisi and Batumi pay GEL20 for a single trip; bus 
passengers pay around GEL18. Limited stops and comfortable premium services would change 
the intercity transport market considerably. Bus ridership would very likely increase. 
3.  Road Subsector Management 
9.  The  responsibility  for  road  building  and  maintenance  is  split  between  the  Roads 
Department  and  the  districts  and  cities.  The  institutional  arrangements  changed  in 
February 2009,  soon  after  MORDI  was  created.  The  Roads  Department  and  the  United 
Transport  Administration  were  transferred  from  the  Ministry  of  Economic  Development  to 
MORDI.  The  Roads  Department  is  solely  responsible  for  building  and  maintaining  the 
international  and  secondary  roads.  Road  maintenance  is  contracted  out  to  private  sector 
companies. Transport policy and strategy is handled by the Ministry of Economic Development. 
The United Transport Administration is primarily responsible for technical regulation and safety, 
and for road, aviation, and maritime transport security. 
 
10.  The Roads Department has 160 staff, nearly all based in Tbilisi. It has small regional 
offices: (i) in Sagarejo, for the Kakheti, Kvemo Kartli, and Mtskheta-Mtianeti regions; (ii) in 
Borjomi,  for  the  Shida  Kartli  and  Samtskhe-Javakheti  regions;  (iii)  in  Kutaisi,  for  the 
Racha-Lechkhumi,  Kvemo  Svaneti,  and  Imereti  regions;  (iv)  in  Poti,  for  the  Guria  and 
Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti regions; and (v) in the Autonomous Republic of Adjara. For the local 
roads, no formal organizational structure has been established as yet; most local governments 
lack technical staff, equipment, and a secure source of funding for road maintenance and

3
rehabilitation. Municipalities are responsible for urban roads. The road sector analysis is in 
Appendix 2. 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Challenges 
11.  Like other sectors in Georgia, the road subsector has been transformed from a centrally 
planned to a market-oriented system since independence. The subsector faces four major 
challenges: (i) inadequate capacity of the road network, including subregional corridors, (ii) 
insufficient  funding  for  capital  investment  and  road  maintenance,  (iii)  unsatisfactory  safety 
record, and (iv) limited institutional capacity. 
 
12.  Road  network  infrastructure.  Georgia’s  road  network  is  a  crucial  component  of 
national and subregional transport and trade infrastructure. The east–west highway is part of the 
Asian highway network connecting Georgia and Turkey to Azerbaijan and Central Asia.1 The 
southern  corridor  connects  the  country  to  Armenia.    Georgia  is  a  signatory  to  several 
international  transport  agreements  and  conventions.  The  continued  development  of  an 
integrated and efficient road network facilitates cross-border and transit traffic and promotes 
subregional cooperation and integration. The existing road network does not adequately serve 
the current needs of the economy and the subregion, and many roads are still in poor condition. 
Funding  for  capital  investment  and  the  maintenance  of  secondary  and  local  roads  is  still 
inadequate. A large part of the network has deteriorated rapidly since the 1990s and is now 
hard to maintain. The resulting increase in transport costs and in traffic accidents has impeded 
faster  growth  and  makes  poverty  reduction  more  difficult.  The  road  subsector  must  be 
developed to facilitate subregional trade, jobs, investment, and tourism. 
 
13.  Capital and maintenance funding. Capital investment finance is limited and dependent 
mostly on budgetary conditions. The private sector and banks are yet to become significant 
player.  Until 2004, there was a road fund, financed from the proceeds of a fuel tax, an 
international  transit  tax,  and  a  road  use  tax  on  individuals  and  enterprises.  In  2004,  the 
Government abolished the road fund and other special funds, and the subsector is now funded 
directly from the state budget and from donor funds. The proceeds of transport-related taxes 
and fees are part of general revenue and not earmarked for road maintenance. The proposed 
maintenance program of the Roads Department for 2009–2013 includes an increase in annual 
funding from $110 million to $137 million, with most of the increase earmarked for periodic 
maintenance.  In  2007,  the  responsibility  for  local  roads  was  transferred  from  the  Roads 
Department  to  69  local  authorities,  as  part  of  broader  public  sector  reform  aimed  at 
decentralizing government functions. About GEL1,450 million is needed to rehabilitate the local 
roads  (90%  are  in  poor  condition)  so  that  they  can  be  maintained.    Routine  and  winter 
maintenance of the rehabilitated local roads would amount to GEL1,500–GEL4,000 per km 
yearly. Road maintenance is a growing need, but funding remains a challenge. Development 
partners coordinate closely with the Roads Department to work on this. The World Bank is 
supporting the Roads Department in improving the efficiency of road maintenance by shifting 
from input-based maintenance to performance-based maintenance contracts. The investment 
program  to  be  financed  by  ADB  will  also  call  for  the  expansion  of  performance-based 
                                                 
1  The concept of an Asian highway network was developed with the assistance of the United Nations Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. Twenty-seven Asian countries (including Georgia) have signed the 
intergovernmental agreement on the Asian highway network.

4   
maintenance contracts and assist the Roads Department in maintaining project roads through 
such contracts.  
 
14.  Road safety. Road safety needs serious attention; there has been a sharp rise in traffic 
accidents, fatalities, and injuries. The current fatality rate is much higher than in European 
countries, and the economic and human losses have been significant. While traffic accidents 
have many causes, the inadequate road network is a factor. Curves and superelevation are 
inappropriately  designed  on  many  roads,  and  safety  furniture  is  lacking.  Other  causes  of 
accidents are weak enforcement of safety regulations, reckless driving, and a larger vehicle 
fleet. The Government needs to take remedial action to curb accidents. The more than 6,000 
accidents in 2008 that involved death or serious injury and killed 867 people represented an 
increase of more than 18% over the 2007 figure. The fatality rate relative to the vehicle fleet, at 
12 per 10,000 vehicles in 2008, is high (removing scrapped vehicles from the fleet statistics 
would result in an even-higher rate)—and exceeds the rate in other European countries.2 Both 
fatalities and serious injuries are on the rise. Road safety has thus become a social concern. 
The Government developed the National Traffic Safety Strategy in 2008 and is now making a 
bigger effort to strengthen law enforcement and launching public campaigns for road safety. 
 
15.  Institutional capacity. Despite recent progress in the reform of institutions, the road 
subsector still has limited institutional capacity. The limitations are reflected in (i) still weak legal 
and regulatory framework for managing the road network; (ii) limited enforcement of some 
regulations, such as those relating to vehicle axle-load controls and road safety; (iii) lack of 
experience  in  and  knowledge  of  public–private  partnerships  for  road  construction  and 
maintenance; and (iv) limited staff experience in managing road projects, particularly where 
tunnel and bridge engineering and environmental and resettlement safeguards are concerned. 
Although some donors have being supporting institutional strengthening, the Roads Department 
needs more assistance, ideally within the context of the proposed investment program.  
 
2.  Opportunities 
 
16.  Georgia  is  the  shortest  transit  link  between  Central  Asia  and  Europe,  the  Russian 
Federation, Azerbaijan, Armenia and Turkey. It is situated on the most direct route from the 
Black Sea to the Caspian Sea and Central Asia. Recognizing the strategic importance as a 
transit route, the Government has given top priority to rehabilitating and upgrading the east–
west highway to international standards. Subregional multi-road corridors will add benefits to 
Georgia and its neighbors. Efficient multi-road corridors connect neighboring countries and 
reduce subregional and international transport costs. Both the local economy and the economy 
of  the  subregion  will  gain  from  these  efforts,  and  Euro–Asia  trade  links  will  develop  and 
strengthen. The subregional multi-road corridors will link major cities, ports, and tourist centers 
within the country, and promote economic growth through more-efficient passenger and freight 
transport.  
 
17.  After the conflict with the Russian Federation in 2008, the Government endorsed the 
joint needs assessment (JNA) prepared by the United Nations together with ADB, the European 
Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development,  the  European  Commission,  the  European 
Investment  Bank,  the  International  Finance  Corporation  and  the  World  Bank.  The  JNA 
recommended a priority recovery and investment program focused on Georgia’s road networks,

5
noting that limited transport infrastructure added to the cost of doing business, discouraged 
foreign investment, made the use of the transit corridor less time and cost effective, and left 
large segments of the population out of the economic mainstream. The JNA also emphasized 
the need for subregional multi-road corridors to provide transit routes that were more efficient 
and secure. The JNA became the basis for development partners’ assistance programming and 
cooperation.  In  2009,  the  Roads  Department  updated  the  road  transport  infrastructure 
development needs brought out in the JNA and identified about 1,842 km of roads—372 km of 
main roads, 470 km of alternative roads, and 1,000 km of secondary and local roads—to  be 
built, upgraded, or rehabilitated. The non-investment component will address priority reforms, 
including  improving  regulations  and  operating  procedures;  support  for  private  sector 
participation in construction and maintenance; and improve capacity to plan, manage, monitor, 
evaluate, measure and report. The overall investment is $3 billion over 7 years. Most of this will 
need  to  be  financed  by  development  aid  agencies,  private  sector  and  banks  and  the 
Government’s budget. The Government is now seeking finance from ADB, the World Bank, the 
Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC), and the Japan International Cooperation Agency 
(JICA). The road map and the investment plan for 2009–2015 are in Appendix 3. This also 
describes the policy framework.  
  3.  ADB’s Strategy and Sector Operations 
18.  ADB’s interim operational strategy for 2008–20093 is centered on nurturing sustainable 
economic  growth,  with  governance,  regional  cooperation,  and  environmental  protection  as 
support  themes.  Core  strategic  areas  include  municipal  infrastructure  services,  road 
transportation and energy infrastructure. ADB has also assisted Georgia with crisis support 
following the conflict with the Russia Federation and the ongoing global financial crisis. With 
regard to the road subsector, ADB is focusing on the main highways connecting Georgia to its 
neighboring countries, policy reform, and capacity. This work is being carried out in partnership 
with the Government and other aid agencies such as the World Bank and JICA. The investment 
program, which was prepared with technical assistance approved by ADB in January 2008,4 is 
consistent with this assistance strategy for Georgia.  ADB is also helping the sector through 
private sector-led transactions.  Besides finance extended in 2008 to the Bank of Georgia, ADB 
is also looking into investment opportunities in the port sector.  These contribute directly to 
regional cooperation and reinforce the investments in road corridors.  
4.  Government’s Strategy and Policy 
19.  The Government attaches top priority to developing its infrastructure and institutional 
setting to reinforce market integration, productivity, competitiveness and the country’s unique 
potential  as  a  transit  economy.  To  execute  this  strategy,  the  Government  intends  to 
(i) strengthen  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  particularly  to  facilitate  private  sector 
participation in building and maintaining the subregional network; (ii) develop the capacity of 
institutions in the road subsector to manage and maintain more the road network efficiently; (iii) 
provide  the  financial  and  technical  resources  that  the  local  authorities  need  to  properly 
discharge their increased responsibility for managing road assets; and (iv) grant concessions to 
the private sector to build and operate the main roads.

5.  External Assistance 
20.  The road subsector has received external assistance since the mid-1990s, mostly from 
the MCC and the World Bank (Appendix 4.) This assistance has chiefly been directed at 
improving the east–west highway and rehabilitating main roads. Civil works on the east–west 
highway are in progress. The Igoeti–Sveneti section work started in 2009, with funding from the 
World Bank, which will also finance improvement works on the Sveneti–Ruisi section and the 
rehabilitation of the Rikoti tunnel in 2010. The Ruisi–Rikoti section (also World Bank) and the 
Zestaponi–Kutaisi–Samtredia section (JICA) will be improved by 2013. With assistance from the 
MCC, Georgia will soon have better access to the Armenia border and to the Turkish border in 
the southwest. The MCC and the World Bank have likewise provided technical assistance for 
feasibility studies and capacity development. Tranche 1 under the proposed MFF from ADB will 
complete essential work on the east–west corridor, and reinforce operations being finance in the 
neighboring countries.  
6.  Lessons  
21.  ADB operations in Georgia are just starting. Thus, there are no substantive lessons from 
previous projects. But operations by other partners do provide hints on risks.  First, each project 
to  be  financed  under  the  MFF  needs  an  in-depth  assessment  of  its  technical,  economic, 
environmental, and social aspects (including land acquisition and resettlement) to establish 
quality at entry. Second, advance contracting is necessary to speed up project implementation. 
Third,  the  road  infrastructure  investments  need  project  management  skills  and  institutional 
accountability to build things on time and within budget. Fourth, the investment program needs 
to be designed in close collaboration with the authorities.  It is also important for the cofinancing 
development partners to work closely together to avoid duplications on technical and policy 
messages.  One lesson learned from other countries is the importance of establishing sound 
cross-border arrangements to cut travel time schedules and costs. 
 
7.   Rationale for ADB Support for the Investment Program 
 
22.  Connectivity, both domestic and international, is the key to sustainable development in 
Georgia. However, rapid growth in traffic up to 2008 and lack of investment since independence 
have greatly diminished the efficiency of subregional corridors. Growth and poverty reduction 
will be affected if the situation is not redressed. The corridors need to increase their capacity, 
new investment and better maintenance. Improved road safety measures and standards, and 
“soft” investments to facilitate cross-border trade and transit traffic, are also needed. 
 
23.  The Roads Department spent an average of GEL199 million yearly in 2004–2008. In 
2009 it expects to spend GEL521 million—44% for new construction, 51% for rehabilitation, and 
5% for routine maintenance. Expenditure is expected to reach GEL1 billion in 2010. ADB, JICA, 
MCC, and the World Bank will help finance the expanded program. The MFF modality will keep 
ADB involved over the long term and give the Government greater certainty in financing, while 
spending more time on project preparation.

7
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
24.  The investment program will promote economic development and subregional trade, and 
accelerate  subregional  cooperation  and  integration.  It  will  create  better  trade  and  logistic 
corridors, and facilitate the cross-border movement of people and cargo. The outcome will be an 
improved subregional road network. The successful implementation of the investment program 
will (i) improve the efficiency of subregional road traffic through Georgia; (ii) increase trade flows 
and competitiveness; (iii) lower transport costs; (iv) increase mobility and access to markets, 
jobs, and social services; and (v) improve governance. 
B.  Outputs 
25.  The outputs will be (i) roads  improved in the subregional road network, (ii) effective and 
efficient  management  of  the  road  network,  and  (iii)  improved  road  safety.  For  the  road 
infrastructure component, priority roads will be built, upgraded, or rehabilitated. The selection of 
roads to be financed under the MFF will be based on the updated JNA and economic, social, 
environmental, and technical assessments. (The selection criteria and approval process for 
projects and subprojects to be financed under the MFF are in Appendix 5.) The management 
capacity component will be concerned with master planning for the road subsector, axle-load 
control, private sector participation in road construction and maintenance, and the design and 
construction of tunnels and bridges. The road safety component will address sustained safety 
training, the adoption of intelligent traffic system technologies, the amendment of regulations to 
incorporate rules for high-speed transport and for tunnel safety, and the development of national 
standards for intelligent traffic systems. 
1.  Outputs for Tranche 1 
26.  The outputs of investments under Tranche 1 of the investment program will be (i) a new 
28 km two-lane bypass road skirting Kobuleti, and a 6 km expansion of an existing two-lane 
road between Kobuleti and Batumi, along the Black Sea coast toward the Turkish border, to four 
lanes; (ii) strengthened asset management capacity of the Road Department; and (iii) improved 
road safety. These outputs will be achieved through four components: (i) the construction of the 
bypass road, (ii) the development of the asset management capacity of the Roads Department, 
(iii)  road  safety  improvement,  and  (iv)  project  management  support  including  consulting 
assistance for detailed design and supervision. 
 
27.  Construction  of  the  Kobuleti  bypass  road.  The  new  bypass  road  to  be  built  in 
project 1  will  comprise  a  3.75-meter-wide  single  carriageway  with  2.5-meter  shoulders, 
18 bridges, and one tunnel. The road will be built to Georgia’s standards for two-lane roads, and 
will  accommodate  speeds  of  100–120  km  per  hour.  (The  road  design  summary  is  in 
Appendix 6.) The road construction activities will comprise (i) civil works, and (ii) land acquisition 
and resettlement. 
 
28.  Capacity  development  at  the  Roads  Department. The Roads Department will be 
assisted to (i) refine the road subsector master plan; (ii) strengthen the capacity of patrol police 
to control axle loads, with the help of portable weighing equipment to be purchased for the 
project and the training of department staff; (iii) introduce public–private partnerships in road 
construction and maintenance, including performance-based maintenance contracting; and (iv)

8   
strengthen  the  department’s  capacity  to  design  and  build  tunnels  and  bridges,  manage 
contracts, and enforce compliance with environmental and resettlement safeguards.   
 
29.  Road safety. Key actions include training Roads Department staff, patrol police, and 
nongovernment  organizations  to  perform  road  safety  audits  and  launch  public  awareness 
campaigns  to  educate  drivers  on  safety,  including  roadside  communities  and  pedestrians 
especially schoolchildren. The program will also finance the acquisition of equipment required 
for road safety enforcement and intelligent traffic systems. 
 
30.  Project management and institutional support. Support will be provided for (i) the 
implementation of investments under  Project 1, including construction supervision, and project 
management, monitoring, and evaluation; (ii) the detailed design of project 2; (iii) environmental 
management expenditure not included in the construction contract packages; (iv) the hiring of 
external experts who will be assigned to the foreign projects unit (FPU) under the Roads 
Department and to assist the unit in implementing the project; and (v) financial auditing by 
independent  external  auditors.  The  work  will  also  include  institutional  change  measures—
including  planning,  regulation  changes,  results  measurement,  safeguards  compliance  and 
reporting.  
2.  Outputs for Tranche 2 
31.  The outputs of the second-tranche project will be (i) a new 14 km two-lane bypass road 
skirting Batumi, (ii) improved border infrastructure for customs with equipment for inspection of 
vehicles  and  passengers,  harmonized  and  simplified  cross-border  procedures  and 
documentation in accordance with international standards, and strengthened capacity of officers 
serving at the border, and (iii) a feasibility study and design work for third-tranche projects. The 
need for capacity development for the Roads Department under the second tranche will be 
assessed on the basis of progress reports.  
C.  Special Features 
32.  Regional  cooperation  and  integration. The investments will contribute to regional 
cooperation and integration by improving the Georgia segment of the trans-Caucasian road 
network. Besides the east–west highway, the southern road corridors will become important 
subregional road corridors and provide a more efficient route for traffic originating in Turkey and 
Armenia and bound for the Caspian Sea and the Black Sea. 
 
33.  Capacity development. The investment program will finance the development of Roads 
Department capacity to manage the road networks and to execute road subsector investments 
on time and within budget. It will also address road maintenance, road safety, vehicle axle-load 
controls, and private sector participation in road construction and maintenance. This assistance 
will supplement the physical investment to sustain the development of the road subsector. 
 
34.  Coordination. The JNA prepared by the Government and development partners in 
September 2008 identified the long-term investment needs in the road subsector in Georgia. 
The development partners agreed to coordinate and harmonize their assistance on the basis of 
the JNA and to help meet the Government’s investment needs as quickly as possible. Since 
then, they have jointly updated the program recommended in the JNA. The present investment 
program is based on the updated JNA. It was prepared in consultation with other development 
partners and will be implemented in close coordination with them, particularly with the World

9
Bank  and  JICA.  Besides  regular  project-based  coordination,  the  development  partners  will 
continue to meet yearly to discuss one another’s ongoing assistance and pipeline. ADB and 
JICA have already entered into a memorandum of understanding to collaborate in assisting the 
countries in the South Caucasus with road and railway subsector road maps and investments.

Regulations  applicable  to  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)–based  loans,  subject  to

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Management

2.  Project Preparation and Appraisal 
39.  Investments under Tranche 1, including all preconstruction activities, such as detailed 
design, contractor prequalification, are under way. Land acquisition and resettlement will be 
completed before the start of civil works. For subsequent investments, the Roads Department, 
with the assistance of the program management support consultants, will prepare (i) the project 
report, including technical, economic, environmental, and social assessments; and (ii) a PFR for 
each  project,  backed  by  a  full  design.  The  project  report  will  conform  to  the  criteria  and 
procedures stated in schedule 4 of the FFA, and other related requirements of the Government 
and ADB. After appraising each project for technical and economic feasibility, compliance with 
safeguard requirements, and completing the final design, the Government will submit to ADB a 
summary appraisal report in the format specified in the investment program administration 
memorandum  and  the  draft  PFR.  ADB  will  then  undertake  due  diligence  according  to  its 
relevant policies and procedures, and approve the appraisal, subject to any amendments. If 
required by ADB, the Roads Department will amend the PFR and submit it to ADB for approval 
by  the  due  date  of  the  PFR.  Meanwhile,  the  Roads  Department  will  carry  out  advance 
contracting under each tranche as approved by ADB to speed up project implementation. 
3.  Implementation Period 
40.  The investment program will be implemented over 7 years (it will be completed by the 
end of 2016). The first-tranche project will be implemented over 4 years (estimated completion 
date:  31 December  2013).  The  Roads  Department  will  prepare  a  detailed  implementation 
schedule for subsequent tranches. An indicative implementation schedule for the investment 
program  and  a  detailed  implementation  schedule  for  investments  under  Tranche  1  are  in 
Appendix 9.   
 
4.  Procurement 
 
41.  Procurement will comply with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from 
time to time). Contracts above $1 million for civil works and above $500,000 for goods will 
undergo international competitive bidding. National competitive bidding, for contracts below 
those  amounts,  will  be  conducted  under  Georgia’s  state  procurement  law,  subject  to  the 
modifications and clarifications stated in the procurement plan. The bulk of the work will be 
structured into a few relatively large contracts. A procurement plan for the investment program 
is in Appendix 10. 
 
5.  Consulting Services 
 
42.  Consulting services will be required for project management and capacity development 
and  road  safety.  Key  tasks  are  (i)  feasibility  studies  and  detailed  design  (ii)  contractor 
engagement and construction supervision (iii) project performance monitoring and reporting and 
results  measurement  (iv)  road  safety  training,  amendment  of  road  safety  regulations,  and 
development of standards for intelligent traffic systems and (v) general capacity development at 
the Roads Department. The Roads Department will select and hire the consultants according to 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time), using 
quality-based selection for the detailed design and supervision consultants and quality- and

12  
cost-based  selection  (80:20  or  other  ratios,  as  appropriate)  for  the  project  management, 
capacity development and road safety improvement. The quality-based selection method is 
justified since the mountainous terrain of the project area requires several long tunnels and 
bridges,  detailed  design  and  construction  supervision  of  which  can  be  supplied  only  by 
technically qualified firms. Other selection modalities will also be considered.  
 
43.  Tranche  1  investments  will  require  1,330  person-months  of  consulting  services 
(230 international  and  1,100  national).  This  comprises  (i) 1,056  person-months  (164 
international  and  892  national)  for  the  detailed  design  of  projects  1  and  2,  construction 
supervision, and project monitoring, evaluation and results measurement; (ii) 31 person-months 
(11 international and 20 national) for road safety; and (iii) 243 person-months (55 international 
and 188 national) for capacity development. Additional consulting services, if necessary, will be 
procured under later tranches. 
 
6.  Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing 
 
44.  To speed up project implementation, starting with Tranche 1, the Government requests 
ADB’s approval under the MFF for advance contracting and retroactive financing of eligible 
expenditures. Advance contracting will allow the Government to start the procurement process 
before the relevant legal agreement is signed. The Government was informed that expenses 
under  advance  contracting  can  be  financed  retroactively  only  if  the  procedures  (including 
advertising)  comply  with  ADB’s Procurement  Guidelines  and  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants. Once first loan is in place, up to 20% of it may retroactively finance eligible 
expenditures  incurred  no  more  than  12  months  before  the  signing  of  the  relevant  legal 
agreement.  Alternatively,  the  Government  may  also  opt  for  advance  contracting  without 
retroactive financing. In that case, the contract for procurement procedures completed under 
advance contracting is awarded after the tranche takes effect. The Government acknowledges 
that ADB’s concurrence with the procedures, documentation, or proposal for award does not 
commit ADB to finance such expenses or the related project. 
7.  Anticorruption Policy 
45.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating  to  the  investment  program.  To 
support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan 
regulations and the bidding documents for the investment program. In particular, all contracts 
financed by ADB in connection with the investment program will include provisions specifying 
the right of ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of the Roads Department, and 
all  contractors,  suppliers,  consultants,  and  other  service  providers  as  they  relate  to  the 
investment program. 
 
46.  The Government and the Roads Department will take additional measures to improve 
governance, accountability, and transparency under the MFF, primarily utilizing direct payment 
procedure.  These  measures  include  (i) independent  external  auditing  of  contracts,  project 
accounts,  and  financial  statements;  (ii) transparent  decisions  on  all  procurement-related 
matters;  (iii)  verification  of  contractors’  payment  claims  by  the  supervision  consultant  in 
accordance with contract specifications; and (iv) timely disclosure of information on the selection 
of consultants and contractors through the Roads Department website.

13
8.  Disbursement Arrangements 
47.  The loan proceeds will be disbursed according to ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook 
(2007, as amended from time to time) primarily utilizing direct payment procedure. To reduce 
cash flow difficulties in the Roads Department and facilitate project implementation, the imprest 
account procedures described in ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook will be followed. An 
imprest account will be established for the treasury service of the Ministry of Finance at the 
National Bank of Georgia after the loan takes effect, and will be liquidated and replenished 
according to ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook. The total advance will not exceed ADB’s 
estimated share of eligible project expenditures to be financed through the imprest account for 
the next 6  months, or  10% of the amount of the loan, whichever is lower. For simplified 
documentation, statement-of-expenditure procedures, as described in the Loan Disbursement 
Handbook, will be followed when reimbursing expenditures and liquidating the imprest account 
for individual payment transactions of up to $100,000 equivalent. 
9.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 
48.  The Government and the Roads Department will adhere to sound financial management 
requirements during the implementation of the investment program. The Roads Department will 
maintain separate project records and accounts adequate to identify the (i) goods and services 
financed  from  the  loan  proceeds,  (ii)  financing  resources  received,  (iii)  project  expenses 
incurred on the components of each project, and (iv) use of counterpart funds. The department 
will hire independent external auditors acceptable to ADB for a yearly audit of the project 
accounts including the imprest account and the statement-of-expenditure procedures. It will 
submit to ADB certified copies of the audited annual project accounts with a separate audit 
opinion on the imprest account and the statement-of-expenditure procedures, as well as the 
auditor’s  report,  in  English  within  6  months  of  the  end  of  each  fiscal  year  during  the 
implementation period. The Roads Department was advised of ADB’s requirement for the timely 
submission of audited annual project accounts, and the suspension of disbursements of ADB 
loans in case of noncompliance with the requirement. 
 
49.  The Roads Department will prepare and submit to ADB quarterly progress reports for 
individual projects, which will include (i) a narrative description of progress made during the 
reporting  period,  (ii)  changes  in  the  implementation  schedule,  (iii)  problems  or  difficulties 
encountered, and (iv) activities to be undertaken in the next reporting period. The department 
will prepare and submit to ADB a project completion report within 3 months of the completion of 
each project, and a program completion report after the completion of all projects under the 
investment program. 
10.  Performance Monitoring and Evaluation, Measuring Results 
50.  Targets and indicators for the monitoring and evaluation of program performance were 
discussed  with  the  Government  (key  performance  targets  and  indicators  are  provided  in 
Appendix 1). The Roads Department will (i) hire consultants for monitoring and evaluation; (ii) 
collect  additional  data  from  relevant  agencies,  including  local  governments  and  statistics 
bureaus, to measure the performance indicators at inception, completion, and 3 years after the 
completion of each project and the investment program; and (iii) report key findings quarterly to 
ADB.  The  department,  with  the  assistance  of  the  supervision  consultant,  will  monitor  and 
evaluate program impact to ensure that the program facilities are managed effectively and the 
program benefits maximized.

14  
11.  Reviews 
51.  ADB will field an inception mission within 3 months of loan approval for each project, and 
various review missions yearly. The Government and ADB will undertake a joint midterm review 
of Tranche 1 investments in 2011 and of the investment program as a whole in 2013. The timing 
of the midterm review of subsequent projects will be agreed on during the appraisal phase of 
each  project.  The  midterm  reviews  will  focus  on  (i)  program  impact,  (ii)  implementation 
progress, (iii) road subsector performance, (iv) performance of consultants and contractors, (v) 
status of compliance with the covenants stipulated in the FFA and individual loan agreements, 
and (vi) the need for any midcourse changes in the scope or schedule of the investment 
program to achieve the full impact of the program. 
IV.  INVESTMENT PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
52.  The investment program will benefit road users, road construction companies, traders, 
logistics companies, and other people who derive income from increased road traffic and trade 
in Georgia. Regarding direct benefits, the improved road network will (i) lower road transport 
and maintenance costs, (ii) speed up road transport services and make them more reliable, 
(iii) reduce travel time for cross-border transit traffic, (iv) reduce traffic accidents, (v) improve 
access to markets and social services, (vi) create jobs and income during implementation 
(through  the  use  of  local  labor  and  construction  materials)  and  after  completion  (through 
roadside business activities), and (vii) reduce air pollution and noise in resort areas where the 
existing road passes. The direct benefits will accrue at the start to vehicle owners and operators 
and  road  construction  companies,  but  will  gradually  be  shared  by  freight  customers  and 
passengers  through  reduced  bus  freight  charges  and  fares.  While  Georgia  is  the  major 
beneficiary, other countries in the region, particularly Armenia and Turkey, will also benefit. The 
investment program, among its indirect benefits, will (i) improve road network management, and 
(ii) increase business activities and jobs with forward or backward linkages to road network 
development. 
 
53.  The construction, under Tranches 1 and 2, of the two bypass roads along the Black 
Sea—(i) from Choloki to Makhinjuari skirting Kobuleti, and (ii) from Makhinjuari to Sarpi skirting 
Batumi—is expected to divert substantial traffic from the existing Poti–Batumi–Sarpi road. The 
existing  road,  which  runs  through  the  urban  areas  of  Batumi  and  Kobuleti,  is  congested, 
accident-prone, and in poor condition. Traffic diverted to the bypass roads will benefit from 
faster transit on a smoother driving surface with better vertical and horizontal alignment and less 
congestion. Traffic that continues to use the existing road will also benefit from a reduction in 
the volume of traffic and, therefore, in congestion. The projects will directly benefit road users, 
road construction companies, traders, and other people who derive income from improved road 
traffic and trade in Georgia. But, in the longer term, the bypass roads will benefit the regional 
economy of the Autonomous Republic of Adjara, where the major industries are tourism and 
citrus fruit exports. Better transport is a key factor in the further development of those industries. 
The  present  Poti–Batumi–Sarpi  road  is  an  integral  transit  corridor  in  Georgia,  connecting 
Azerbaijan, Armenia, and the Central Asian countries with Turkey. These countries will also 
benefit from more-efficient movement of transit traffic because of the bypass roads.

15
B.  Economic Analysis 
54.  An  economic  analysis  of  all  projects  financed  under  the  MFF  will  be  conducted 
according to ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects.10 An economic analysis 
was carried out for the two bypass roads, as these are a contiguous stretch of road, despite 
phased  financing  under  projects  1  and  2  (Appendix  11).  The  analysis  was  based  on  a 
comparison of with- and without-project cases and covered a period of 20 years after the 
projects start full operation in 2014. To forecast the traffic, projections were made for the 
following: (i) normal traffic in the without-project case, (ii) diverted traffic from the existing road to 
the bypass roads, and (iii) generated traffic. According to the projections, the average daily 
traffic on the existing coast road and the bypass roads will increase from about 6,944 in 2010 to 
20,478 in 2033.  
 
55.  The major benefit from the projects will be savings in travel time of about 30%–50% for 
all types of vehicles. Savings in vehicle operating cost per kilometer and a reduction in traffic 
accidents by nearly half are also expected. The savings in vehicle operating costs per kilometer 
were projected to be 10% for goods vehicles and articulated trucks, 19% for large buses, and 
about 10% for medium and mini buses. The highway design and maintenance 4 (HDM-4) model 
was used in projecting the benefits. 
 
56.  The economic analysis showed the project to be economically viable, with an estimated 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  14.3%  and  an  estimated  net  present  value  of 
$45.0 million at a 12% discount rate. Sensitivity analysis confirmed the economic viability of the 
projects. A 20% decrease in traffic growth would lead to an EIRR marginally below 12%. The 
risk analysis indicated that the mean and median EIRRs, though lower than the base-case EIRR 
of 14.3%, were above the cutoff level of 12%. The project has 79.8% probability of positive net 
present value, or an EIRR higher than 12%. 
C.  Financial Management and Sustainability 
57.  A financial analysis of projects financed under the MFF, if necessary, will be conducted 
according  to  ADB’s  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of  Projects.11 Project  1  is  not  a 
revenue-generating project and does not require financial analysis. A financial management 
assessment of ETCIC, based on questionnaires and field interviews, was undertaken to assess 
its ability to fulfill ADB’s fiduciary requirements for the investment program. The ETCIC uses 
modified cash-basis accounting and runs accounting software that was considered satisfactory 
for accounting and reporting by the World Bank in its January 2009 financial management 
supervision report. The ETCIC has a financial and accounting management manual, most 
recently updated in January 2009, and audits of its project accounts have been satisfactory. To 
ensure  proper  fiduciary  oversight  of  ETCIC,  independent  external  auditing  of  contracts, 
accounts, and financial statements will be undertaken under project 1. The Roads Department 
has adequate capacity for financial management with the assistance of ETCIC. 
 
58.  Since the conflict with the Russian Federation in 2008 and the global financial crisis that 
followed, the foreign debt of Georgia has been closely monitored by development partners, 
particularly by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). A large portion of foreign assistance since 
the conflict has been on concessionary terms. The IMF set an annual ceiling of $800 million on 
non-concessionary lending to Georgia on the basis of its analysis of Georgia’s debt service

D.  Environmental Impact 
59.  An environmental assessment of all projects financed under the MFF will be conducted 
according to the environmental assessment and review framework prepared by the Government 
and agreed on with ADB in compliance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) or, if applicable, 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009)12, and Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003), as 
well as relevant laws and regulations in Georgia. An environmental impact assessment (EIA) of 
project 1, a category A project, was prepared. The summary EIA was circulated to the Board 
and publicly disclosed through the ADB website on 29 May 2009. The EIA concluded that the 
overall environmental impact of project 1 would be both positive and negative, and that the 
negative  impact  could  be  minimized  by  adequate  mitigation  measures  included  in  the 
environmental management plan. When projects are identified and processed under the third 
and  subsequent  tranches,  the  cumulative  environmental  impact  of  the  entire  MFF  will  be 
assessed. The environmental assessment and review framework is in Supplementary Appendix 
E.  
 
60.  The Kobuleti bypass road under project 1 is at a sufficient distance from the safe buffer 
zone  of  the  protected  areas—Kobuleti  Nature  Reserve  and  Kobuleti  Managed  Reserve, 
important wetlands and an internationally significant Ramsar site. The proposed alignment will 
have no major impact on the Ramsar site. It will neither block known animal migration trails nor 
intersect any known protected species of flora or fauna along the alignment. Contractors will 
avoid  bridge  substructure  (foundation)  work  during  the  known  spawning  season  for  rivers 
traversed by the project road. No historical, cultural, or archaeological sites are within the 
project area. Some trees will be cut, but civil works contractors will be required to replant trees. 
Noise barriers will be recommended in selected locations of the bypass roads where noise 
exceeds  local  standards.  Retaining  structures  to  protect  unstable  batters  and  potential 
geo-hazards, and riverbank protection measures will be considered in the engineering design. 
Complete fencing on both sides of the bypass roads between densely populated settlements, 
coupled with improved signage and controlled access, will substantially improve safety for local 
residents.  Measures,  including  the  following,  will  be  taken  during  construction,  to  restrict 
encroachment into protected areas: (i) no construction camp will be located from Km 6 to Km 14 
in the protected-area section of the road; (ii) asphalt and mixing plants will be set up outside the 
protected-area section; (iii) solid waste in the nature reserve will be strictly managed; (iv) a 
fence will be built around the protected-area section; and (v) road signs, an awareness display 
board, and bylaws will be developed to explain and deal with violations and encroachments. 
The overall impact of project 1 on the environment is considered manageable. 
E.  Poverty and Social Impact 
61.  A poverty and social analysis of all projects financed under the MFF will be conducted 
according to ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic 
Analysis of Projects13  and Handbook on Social Analysis.14 (A summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy for project 1 is in Appendix 12.) The project road will traverse two regions, Adjara

17
and Guria, and will pass through the districts of Ozurgeti and Khelvachauri and the cities of 
Kobuleti and Batumi, with a total population of 379,472. A sample socioeconomic survey in 
20 villages in the project area (200 samples) revealed that about 52% of the people live below 
the poverty line.  
 
62.  The direct benefit of the investment program on the poor will be relatively small, except 
that it will provide some direct employment opportunities during construction. The benefits to the 
poor will be more indirect. The provision of transport services, including the construction and 
maintenance of transport infrastructure, will generate demand for labor (often unskilled labor) 
and provide income-earning opportunities for the poor. A transport project that generates jobs 
for the poor who are otherwise unemployed or underemployed contributes indirectly to poverty 
reduction. The construction aspect of transport sector development is often viewed as equally 
important  as  the  service  aspect  in  promoting  economic  growth.  The  process  of  poverty 
reduction is rooted in a broad range of socioeconomic activities to which transport services have 
an intermediate contribution. 
 
63.  The investment program will have both short-term and long-term positive impact. The 
short-term positive impact will include access to markets for agricultural produce, availability of 
temporary unskilled jobs for villagers, and opportunity to provide food and restaurant services 
for construction workers. The long-term positive impact will include access to long-distance 
transport  services  across  the  border,  access  to  long-distance  markets  (buying  and  selling 
through regional trade), easier access to health facilities and medical treatment, increased 
access to agricultural extension services, increased access to education, increased opportunity 
for the development of tourism, and diversification of income sources.  
 
64.  Women have important economic roles in project areas and engage in a very wide range 
of income-generating activities in the agricultural and marketing sector. The investment program 
will pay particular attention to women, to ensure that they are rightly compensated for their 
activities and that women who are effectively household heads are clearly listed as beneficiaries 
of compensation and rehabilitation proceedings under the investment program. Women will also 
participate in the consultation processes to determine and negotiate compensation entitlements 
and implement the land acquisition and resettlement plan. Special attention will be given to the 
impact  of  resettlement  on  women  and  other  vulnerable  groups  during  the  monitoring  and 
evaluation of the land acquisition and resettlement plan. The investment program will have a 
positive impact on gender, as the civil works contracts will include provisions to encourage the 
employment of women during implementation, and women will be encouraged to participate in 
activities to monitor program impact.  
 
65.  All projects financed under the MFF will include public awareness campaigns and other 
appropriate  measures  to  mitigate  the  potential  risk  of  HIV  and  other  sexually  transmitted 
infections, as well as drug and human trafficking. Civil works contractors will be required to take 
measures to protect construction workers from the risks of HIV and other sexually transmitted 
infections, and to give construction workers time to be tested or receive treatment.  
 
66.  The  impact  on  indigenous  peoples  was  assessed  according  to  ADB’s  Policy  on 
Indigenous Peoples (1998). The investment program will primarily affect Georgians, who make 
up almost 93% of the population. Other ethnic groups in the project area—mostly Armenian, 
Azeri, and Russian—are insignificant in number. These groups have been fully integrated into 
institutional, cultural, and economic processes in the country, and do not display sufficient 
features to be classified as indigenous peoples according to the ADB definition. Therefore, 
project 1 is classified as category C.
