F.  Social Safeguards 
67.  The impact on land acquisition and resettlement of all projects financed under the MFF 
will be assessed according to the land acquisition and resettlement framework (LARF) prepared 
by the Government and agreed on with ADB in compliance with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement 
Policy (1995) or, if applicable, Safeguard Policy Statement (footnote 12), and relevant laws and 
regulations  in  Georgia.  The  LARF  (Supplementary  Appendix  F)  specifies  compensation 
provisions  and  procedures  for  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement plans (LARPs) for projects financed under the MFF.  
 
68.  Tranche  1  investment  will  entail  substantial  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  and, 
hence, is considered a category A project. According to the census survey, 163.3 hectares (ha) 
of land—134.8 ha of agricultural land, 26.1 ha of nonagricultural or pasture land, and 2.4 ha of 
residential and commercial land—will need to be acquired. A total of 740 land parcels, and 
154 structures or buildings, will be affected. The affected households or families number 881 
(including 332 vulnerable households)—200 titleholders, 562 households that can be legalized, 
and 119 non-titleholders. The total number of affected persons is 4,440. (A full LARP is in 
Supplementary Appendix G and a summary is in Appendix 13.) The LARF and the LARP for 
project 1 were endorsed by the Roads Department and disclosed to the affected people. The 
updated LARP will be submitted to ADB for review and the final LARP agreed on between 
MORDI and ADB will be fully implemented before the start of civil works. 
 
69.  LARPs for future projects, with the land acquisition and resettlement impact, will be 
prepared  according  to  the  LARF,  and  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  for  approval  and  fully 
implemented before the start of civil works. The appraisal of subsequent projects financed under 
the MFF will require a review of the LARF and the preparation of the respective LARPs, with the 
land acquisition and resettlement impact. The implementation of the LARPs will be a condition 
for the start of civil works under the relevant projects. 
G.  Assumptions and Risks 
70.  The investment program rests on several assumptions: (i) continued macroeconomic 
stability in Georgia, (ii) effective implementation of the JNA, (iii) the Government’s continued 
commitment to regional cooperation, (iv) the Government’s commitment to implementing the 
road map and the investment program, and (v) adequate financing. The program also needs 
investments in the neighboring countries and cross-border agreements to speed up document 
clearance and cut costs and travel time. 
 
71.  Risks  to  the  investment  program  include  (i)  low  coordination  among  government 
agencies during implementation, (ii) rapid deterioration of the road network caused by weak 
axle-load controls and insufficient funding for maintenance, (iii) delays in the preparation and 
implementation of subsequent projects, and (iv) delays in the start of project implementation 
caused  by  inadequate  design  and  preconstruction  works.  The  investment  program  needs 
coordinated investments in the neighboring countries. The Government has taken the necessary 
measures to minimize these risks. MORDI and the Ministry of Finance will coordinate the work 
of the agencies so that execution issues are resolved promptly. The Government is committed 
to enforcing axle-load controls and further increasing funding for road maintenance. ADB, with 
its partners, will provide sustained support to the Roads Department to strengthen its capacity to 
manage the road network. Adequate consulting services will be provided to help the Roads 
Department  prepare  subsequent  projects,  manage  implementation,  monitor  performance,

19
measure results and report to ADB. With its own funds the Government has begun detailed 
design and other preconstruction works to be ready to start construction once the investment 
program is approved by ADB. Other countries in the region are investing in their own sections of 
the corridors.  ADB is also a cofinancier in these cases. Cross-border and trade facilitation work 
is  being  developed  under  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Cooperation  Program  (CAREC).  The 
implementation of the physical infrastructure components will be accompanied with work to 
speed up border crossing and cut paperwork.  Technical assistance will be put in place for this 
purpose.   
V.  ASSURANCES 
A.  Specific Assurances 
72.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, and assurances agreed to in the FFA, which will be incorporated in the legal 
documents: 
 
(i)  Road subsector master plan. The Government will refine a long-term road subsector 
development plan and adopt it for implementation by 31 December 2011. Such a plan 
will  provide  policy  actions  and  measures  to  (a)  update  the  system  for  efficient 
planning and prioritization of road maintenance works; (b) develop or adopt adequate 
road maintenance standards; and (c) provide training to strengthen the capacity of  
Roads Department. 
 
(ii)  Policy  dialogue.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  ADB  is  kept  informed  of 
Georgia’s policies and programs related to the road subsector that will materially 
affect the economic viability of each project, subproject, or component financed 
under the MFF. 
 
(iii)  Road maintenance. The Government will ensure that actual annual expenditures for 
road maintenance (including emergency maintenance, but excluding rehabilitation 
and  new  construction)  for  roads  within  the  Roads  Department’s  jurisdiction  are 
increased at least at the same rate as increases in the overall national budget during 
2010–2015. 
 
(iv)  Construction quality. The Government will ensure that (a) the project roads under 
the  investment  program  are  rehabilitated  or  constructed  in  accordance  with  the 
technical  specifications  of  the  design,  without  exceeding  the  construction  cost 
estimate, and within the timeframe agreed upon; and (b) construction supervision, 
quality  control,  and  contract  management  are  performed  in  accordance  with 
internationally acceptable standards. The works, goods, services procured for each 
project under the MFF will be monitored continuously and evaluated periodically so 
that the designs, professional conduct, and outputs, as the case may be, are in 
accordance with the relevant national, regional, and international standards, criteria, 
best practices, and agreements, and are in compliance with relevant ADB's policies. 
 
(v)  Transparency  and  good  governance.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  all 
contracts  financed  by  ADB  under  the  investment  program  include  provisions 
specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of the

20  
implementing agency and all contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service 
providers  as  they  relate  to  the  project  in  question.  An  independent  auditor  will 
conduct periodic audits of project accounts, and the Government will ensure that 
corrective or preventive action is taken to prevent misallocation of resources. 
 
(vi)  Outsourcing of road maintenance. The Government will ensure that the Roads 
Department  enters  into  a  pilot  performance-based  maintenance  contract  with  a 
private sector entity by 2011.  
 
(vii)  Road  safety.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  Roads  Department  installs 
appropriate road safety signs and facilities during project implementation and after 
completion, such as warning signs, pavement markings, road signs and signals, and 
hazard barriers, all in compliance with appropriate international conventions that 
Georgia is a signatory to and best industry practices. The Roads Department will 
ensure  monitoring  of  the  accident  rate  and  traffic  volume  after  the  start  of  the 
operation of the roads financed under the MFF, and institute appropriate safety 
enforcement measures. 
 
(viii)  Environment. The Government will ensure that the projects under the investment 
program are designed, carried out, maintained, and monitored in compliance with 
(a) all  applicable  environmental  laws  and  regulations;  (b) ADB’s  Environment 
Policy (2002) or, if applicable, Safeguard Policy Statement (footnote 12); (c) the 
environmental  assessment  and  review  framework;  and  (d) the  environmental 
management  plan  (EMP),  including  the  mitigation  measures  and  monitoring 
requirements arising from the implementation of the EIA. The Government will 
also ensure that (a) civil works contractors’ specifications include requirements to 
comply with the environmental mitigation measures contained in the EIA and the 
EMP, and (b) civil works contractors are supervised to ensure compliance with the 
requirements of the EIA and the EMP. 
 
(ix)  Land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  land 
acquisition and resettlement are carried out promptly and efficiently following the 
land acquisition and resettlement plan agreed on with ADB in line with applicable 
laws  and  regulations  and  ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995),  or,  if 
applicable, Safeguard Policy Statement (footnote 12). The Government will ensure 
that the implementation of the land acquisition and resettlement plan is monitored, 
evaluated,  and  reported  to  ADB  as  required  in  the  resettlement  plan.  The 
Government  will  also  ensure  that  all  land  and  right-of-way  required  for  project 
implementation are made available in a timely manner. 
 
(x)  Local  consultation  and  gender.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  all  local 
consultations  to  address  safety,  social,  and  cultural  issues  during  project 
implementation are carried out as recommended in the summary poverty reduction 
and social strategy (Appendix 12). The Government will further ensure that men and 
women are given equal employment opportunities directly or indirectly arising from 
the investment program and without any differentiation in wages for equal work. The 
mechanisms  for  maximizing  local  employment  benefits  shall  be  included  in  the 
bidding documents. 
 
(xi)  Labor. The Government will ensure that all civil works contractors (a) comply with all 
applicable labor laws; (b) use their best efforts to employ women and local people,

21
including disadvantaged people, living in the vicinity of the project or subproject 
financed under the MFF; (c) disseminate information at worksites on the risks of 
sexually transmitted infections for those employed during construction; (d) provide 
equal pay to men and women for work of equal type; (e) provide safe working 
conditions for male and female workers; and (f) abstain from child labor. Contracts 
for all projects and subprojects financed under the investment program must include 
specific clauses on these undertakings, and compliance will be strictly monitored 
during implementation. 
 
(xii)  Health  risks  and  prevention.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  civil  works 
contracts include a requirement to conduct an information and education campaign on 
sexually transmitted diseases and HIV for construction workers as part of the health 
and safety program at campsites during the construction period. 
 
(xiii)  Illegal trafficking. The Government will undertake concrete and adequate measures 
to detect and prevent trafficking of humans, wildlife, endangered species, and illegal 
substances on the project roads. 
 
(xiv)  Change in ownership and operation. If any of the following is anticipated: (a) any 
change  in  ownership  of  the  road,  road  facility,  or  structure  financed  under  the 
investment program; (b) any sale, transfer, or assignment of interest or control in the 
road, road facility, or structure financed under the investment program; or (c) any 
lease or other contract or modification of the functions and authority of the Roads 
Department  over  the  operation  and  maintenance  of  any  road,  road  facility,  or 
structure financed under the investment program; then the Government will ensure 
that ADB’s consent is obtained at least 6 months prior to the implementation of such 
a plan. The Government will ensure that any such changes will be carried out in a 
legal and transparent manner. 
B.  Conditions for Disbursemen 
73.  Conditions under Tranche 1 Project. No loan proceeds shall be disbursed for civil 
works  for  the  construction  of  the  Kobuleti  bypass  until  (i)  the  Government  has  allocated 
adequate funds to a project account for land acquisition and resettlement activities, and (ii) the 
land and rights-of-way required for the project 1 road are free and clear from the rights or claims 
of third parties and any other encumbrances. 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
74.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the 
President under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, recommend 
that the Board approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an 
aggregate amount not exceeding $500,000,000 equivalent to Georgia for the Road Corridor 
Investment Program comprising: 
 
(i)  a loan in various currencies equivalent to 75,892,000 Special Drawing Rights 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0%

per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and a term of

ROAD SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS  
A.  Transport Sector Overview   
1.  Georgia borders Armenia, Azerbaijan, the Russian Federation, and Turkey and is the 
lynchpin in the Europe–Caucasus–Asia transport network. It is a small country, to the south of 
the main Caucasus mountain range, with a population of 4.4 million. After independence in 
1991, output declined by 70%, with the loss of Soviet markets, the end of large budget transfers 
from Moscow, and the impact of civil war and ethnic conflicts, which displaced some 300,000 
people. By 2000, recorded gross domestic product (GDP) was only 30%–35% of its 1989 level, 
although there is a (large) shadow economy, estimated to be up to 33% of GDP. Per capita 
income is at the lower end of the scale for lower-middle-income countries. 
 
2.  Georgia enjoys a strategic location it has yet to fully capitalize on. It is on the shortest 
route from Europe to Azerbaijan, Armenia, and the Central Asian countries through its Black 
Sea ports, Poti and Batumi. It can also link the Russian Federation and Turkey. Its physical 
location makes Georgia a key transport link on the most direct route from the Black Sea to the 
Caspian Sea and Central Asia—the historic Silk Road, which the current Transport Corridor 
Europe–Caucasus–Asia  (TRACECA)  initiative  seeks  to  emulate.  Trade  with  neighboring 
countries, both transit and bilateral, is thus an important feature of the economy. Georgia is also 
developing closer economic cooperation with Azerbaijan and Turkey.  
 
3.  Poor infrastructure and cumbersome processes inhibit the full exploitation of transit 
economy potential. Traffic flows from the Caspian Sea, primarily crude oil and oil products, are 
rapidly expanding. The main flow in the corridor is unidirectional, consisting primarily of oil and 
oil products, moving west to Poti and Batumi. Non-oil traffic mostly comprises Armenian and 
Azeri trade goods, which account for a significant share of the turnover of Georgia’s ports. 
Georgia has not yet been able to realize the transit potential from Central Asian countries. 
Designed at a time of much-higher traffic, the transport infrastructure can handle significant 
additional traffic growth with limited new construction, although the aging rail, road, and port 
infrastructure  requires  significant  investments  to  rehabilitate  and  modernize,  after  years  of 
maintenance neglect. Despite being the closest maritime gateway to nearly all Central Asian 
countries, the Georgian route now accounts for a negligible portion of the foreign trade of these 
countries. Long transit times, poor road conditions, the multiple borders to be crossed, and the 
number of times cargoes need to be handled, together with formal and informal payments and 
delays, explain the limited use of the Caucasus route. The significant reduction in corruption 
should improve Georgia’s transit competitiveness. 
 
4.  Limited transport infrastructure adds to the cost of doing business and leaves much of 
the population out of the national economy. Infrastructure constraints add to the cost of doing 
business, deter foreign investment, add time and costs to the transit corridor, and leave large 
segments of the population out of mainstream economic activities. Analyses show a close 
correlation between poverty in rural households and the extent to which the households are 
linked to markets. Poor transport infrastructure partly explains why almost two-thirds of rural 
household agricultural production is for self-subsistence and about 20% of rural households do 
not trade at all. A World Bank rural infrastructure survey revealed that only in 5% of surveyed 
communities were roads repaired within the last 5 years, while in 41% of communities they were 
last  repaired  over  15  years  ago.  Poor  connectivity  has  also  contributed  to  weak  linkages 
between  farmers  and  agro-processors,  as  few  intermediate  agents,  wholesalers,  or 
farmer-based organizations exist.

Appendix 2  29
 
5.  The Government’s transport strategy is to support market integration, to develop the 
infrastructure  and  institutional setting,  and  to maximize  the  country’s  potential as  a  transit 
economy. Implementation progress has been impressive. Concessions for the main ports and 
airports have been granted to the private sector; the railways are developing profit centers and 
adopting  modern  marketing  techniques;  customs  has  been  reformed,  to  improve  trade 
facilitation and reduce corruption; local infrastructure has been devolved to local governments; 
and a massive effort is being made, with the support of international financial institutions, to 
upgrade  the  road  network  and  reduce  travel  costs.  The  sector  agenda  includes  major 
challenges: (i) overhauling the legal and regulatory framework to incorporate the right balance in 
the  public–private  sector  interface  and  ensure  fair  competition,  safety,  and  attention  to 
environmental concerns; (ii) strengthening institutions to fulfill their policy-making, monitoring, 
and  executory  roles;  (iii)  careful  implementation  of  decentralization  to  ensure  that  local 
authorities  acquire  the  technical  and  financial  resources  necessary  to  deal  with  their  new 
obligations;  (iv)  ensuring  capabilities  for  efficient  road  management,  based  on  modern 
information systems; and (v) capitalizing on the benefits of a transit economy, and the ability to 
compete  with  alternative  routes,  requiring  a  concerted  public–private  effort  to  design  and 
implement a vision that significantly transcends the transport sector. 
 
6.  The  transport  infrastructure  consists  of  roads,  railways,  ports,  and  airports.  Road 
transport accounted for 89% of domestic passenger-kilometers (passenger-km) and 8% of 
freight ton-km in 2008 (Table A2.1). The transport sector was one of the fastest growing in the 
economy in 2003–2008. Transport, storage, and communications have substantially increased 
their contribution to the total output, from 4.6% of GDP in 1996 (GEL881 million) to over 10% in 
2007 (GEL1,231 million).

B.   Road Infrastructure 
7.  Georgia’s road network is crucial in facilitating subregional transport and trade. The 
east–west highway forms part of the Asian highway network1 connecting Georgia and Turkey to 
Azerbaijan and Central Asia. Georgia is a signatory to a number of international transport 
agreements and conventions. The continued development of an integrated and efficient road 
                                                 
1  The concept of an Asian highway network was developed with the assistance of the United Nations Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. Twenty-seven Asian countries including Georgia have signed the 
intergovernmental agreement on the Asian highway network.

30  Appendix 2 
network will facilitate cross-border and transit traffic and contribute to subregional cooperation 
and integration. 
 
8.  The road network was primarily developed under the former Soviet Union and does not 
adequately cater to the current needs of the economy and of the subregion. Funding for the 
maintenance of secondary and local roads remains inadequate. A large part of the network has 
deteriorated rapidly since the 1990s and is now impossible to maintain. The resulting increase in 
transport costs and in traffic accidents has impeded growth and poverty reduction. The road 
subsector needs to be developed to facilitate subregional trade, investment, and tourism. 
9.  The length of the road network in 2008 was 20,329 km (Table A2.2). The international 
and interstate roads under the jurisdiction of the Roads Department accounted for one-third of 
the length. The road network was primarily developed under the former Soviet Union. Because 
of insufficient funding for road maintenance after independence, about 24% of the secondary 
road network under the Roads Department, together with most of the local road network, was in 
poor condition in 2008. The international roughness index (IRI) for subregional corridor roads is 
below 4 for 66% of the roads, 4–6 for 28% of the roads, and above 6 for 6% of the roads. Many 
secondary and local roads require reconstruction or rehabilitation. The poor condition of these 
roads raises transport costs and makes the roads less safe. Rigid technical standards and 
specifications for road design, construction, and maintenance mostly dating back to the Soviet 
era consider only traffic volume and not level of service or economic viability in road capacity 
upgrades. The Government has recognized that of such outdated standards are not suited to a 
market-based economy and introduced new standards based on European benchmarks in 
2009. 
 
10.  The main road network at the end of 2008 was 6,941 km in total length, 347 km of this 
total within Adjara. The local road network is about 13,480 km (952 km in Adjara). The length of 
both the main and the local networks has changed little since 2000, the investment emphasis 
having been on rehabilitation rather than network extension. All but 55 km of the 1,495 km of 
international roads are paved, but only 61% of interstate roads, and 23% of local roads, are 
paved. The paved proportion of the national network has hardly changed since 2000. National 
road density is 290 km per 1,000 square kilometers (km2) and Adjaran road density is 160 km 
per 1,000 km2. In comparison, Azerbaijan has 690 km per 1,000 km2 (both paved and unpaved 
roads) and Armenia 270 km per 1,000 km2 (paved roads only).

11.  The principal subregional corridor is the east–west highway (E-60) and the adjoining 
E-70, which connects Asia and Europe. It runs north from the Turkish border at Sarpi, via the 
Black Sea port of Batumi to the port of Poti, then east via the second-largest city, Kutaisi, to 
Tbilisi, and southeast to the border with Azerbaijan at Red Bridge. Three corridors run south 
from Tbilisi to the Armenian border at Sadakhlo, Guguti, and south of Ninotsminda.

Appendix 2  31
C.  Vehicle Fleet  
12.  Vehicle fleet statistics are of poor quality and overstate the number of vehicles in regular 
use. The total fleet in 2008 comprised 613,000 vehicles, of which 543,000 were passenger 
vehicles,  58,000  goods  vehicles,  and  12,000  other  vehicles  (Table  A2.3).  Average  annual 
growth from 2000 to 2008 was 12%. Vehicle ownership per 1,000 population increased from 56 
in 2000 to 140 in 2008. Car ownership is broadly consistent with the level in neighboring 
countries, given differences in per capita GDP. The increase in vehicle ownership is attributable 
to sustained economic growth (GDP per head grew by an average annual rate of 7.9% in 2001–
2008), helped by tariff reductions following accession to the World Trade Organization in 1999. 
The fleet has been modernized to some extent, as Soviet-era vehicles have been replaced by 
Western and Japanese imports, improving vehicle safety and reducing fuel consumption by 
individual vehicles and fuel emissions. Most private vehicles are 10–20 years old and many 
people cannot afford to replace or properly maintain them. The vehicle fleet still includes many 
Soviet-era cars, which generally consume more fuel and produce more emissions. Many buses 
are also in poor condition.

D.  Institutional Structure 
13.  Institutional arrangements (Figure A2) changed in February 2009 when a new ministry 
was created—the Ministry of Regional Development and Infrastructure (MORDI). The Roads 
Department  and  the  United  Transport  Administration  were  transferred  from  the  Ministry  of 
Economic Development to the new ministry. The Roads Department is solely responsible for the 
construction and maintenance of the main road network, all of which is contracted out to private 
sector companies. Strategy and planning are handled by the Transport Department (whose line 
ministry is the Ministry of Economic Development). The United Transport Administration is 
primarily responsible for international aspects of road haulage, aviation, and maritime transport.

14.  The Roads Department has 160 staff, nearly all based in Tbilisi. (The organization chart 
is in Appendix 8.) It has five small regional offices: (i) in Sagarejo, for the Kakheti, Kvemo Kartli, 
and Mtkheta-Mtianeti regions; (ii) in Borjomi, for the Shida Kartli and Samcke-Javakheti regions; 
(iii) in Kutaisi, for the Racha-Lechkhumi, Kvemo Svaneti, and Imereti regions; (iv) in Poti, for the 
Guria and Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti regions; and (v) in the Autonomous Republic of Adjara. For 
the local roads, no formal organizational structure has been established as yet; most local 
governments  lack  technical  staff,  equipment,  and  a  secure  source  of  funding  for  road 
maintenance and rehabilitation.  
15.  Responsibility  for  road  construction  and  maintenance  is  split  between  the  Roads 
Department,  districts,  and  cities.  The  Roads  Department  is  responsible  for  the  main  road 
network, comprising international roads (those used by international transit traffic) and interstate 
roads. Intercity bus transport is completely deregulated and there is no official control of prices. 
The same applies to domestic freight transport. Institutional capacity in the road subsector 
needs further strengthening for the successful expansion of the road program. The World Bank 
is continuing to support necessary institutional strengthening, and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will work in parallel, to enhance resource provision for these initiatives. 
E.  Road Investment Financing 
16.  Consolidated budget revenues increased by more than 10 percentage points of GDP 
between 2003 and 2006. Tax revenues increased substantially, partly owing to the sweeping tax 
reform adopted in 2005, but also because of the crackdown on smuggling and tax evasion since 
the  Rose  Revolution.  The  Government  acknowledges  that  sustaining  and  accelerating 
economic  growth  will  require  deepening  integration  with  world  markets.  To  that  end,  the 
Government has identified as a key priority the modernization and improvement of transport 
infrastructure. Reforms implemented since 2004, along with investments in infrastructure and 
improvements in the regulatory environment, are supporting private sector growth. In the longer 
term, expected sources of growth include agro-processing and small manufacturing, tourism, 
transit trade activities, and mineral extraction and processing. 
17.  In 2005–2006 annual licensing of vehicles stopped and was replaced by a requirement 
to register only when there is a change of ownership. Vehicle registration and driver licensing is 
handled by the police. There are no longer any vehicle roadworthiness tests and owners are not

Appendix 2  33
obliged to carry even third-party insurance. (The abolition of annual licensing accounts for the 
unreliability of vehicle ownership statistics: there is no mechanism for determining whether a 
vehicle is still in use on the road.)

18.  Until 2004 there was a road fund, financed from the proceeds of the fuel tax, the 
international  transit  tax,  and  a  road  use  tax  on  individuals  and  enterprises.  In  2004  the 
Government abolished the road fund and other special funds, and the subsector is now funded 
directly  from  the  state  budget  and  from  development  partner  funds.  The  proceeds  of 
transport-related taxes and fees (fuel tax, import duties and value-added tax on vehicle sales, 
vehicle registration fees, and the Rikoti tunnel tolls) are part of general revenue and are not 
earmarked.   
19.  The budget of the Roads Department for 2009 is GEL521 million (Table A2.4). This is 
financed: GEL284 million from the state budget (GEL102 million of this in counterpart funds) 
and  GEL237  million  from  donor  grants  and  credits.  Routine  maintenance  accounts  for 
GEL26 million  (GEL3,800  per  km).  The  department  has  GEL119  million  in  state  funds  for

periodic  maintenance  and  rehabilitation.  Including  donor-funded  rehabilitation  projects,  total 
funding for rehabilitation and periodic maintenance amounts to GEL150 million, or GEL22,000 
per km. 
F.  Road Maintenance 
20.  Since 2004, the Government has invested some GEL900 million in road construction, 
rehabilitation,  and  maintenance,  with  financial  assistance  from  the  German  development 
cooperation through KfW, the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), the Kuwait 
Fund, the Millennium Challenge Corporation (a US government agency), and the World Bank. 
Foreign assistance to the road subsector is increasing. Sustained financing will continue to be 
needed to bring the network (particularly secondary and local roads) to a maintainable standard, 
while  adding  essential  additional  capacity  to  meet  the  needs  of  trade  (transit),  rural 
development, agriculture, industry, and tourism. Increased mobility and access to secondary 
urban centers is expected to help with job creation.  
21.  The condition of the network under the responsibility of the Roads Department improved 
considerably in 2004–2008 with the rehabilitation and periodic maintenance of 1,722 km. The 
percentage of the main road network in good condition increased from 45% to 66%, although 
the improvement of secondary roads was much less, from 18% to 23%. While only 6% of the 
main network was in poor condition in 2008, 24% of the secondary network was.  
 
22.  Under  the  proposed  Roads  Department  maintenance  program  for  2009–2013,  an 
increase in funding from $110 million to $137 million is planned, with most of the increase going 
to the periodic maintenance program (Table A2.5).

23.  In 2007, responsibility for local roads was transferred from the Roads Department to 69 
local authorities, as part of broader public sector reform aimed at decentralizing government 
functions. About GEL1,450 million is needed to rehabilitate the local roads (90% are in poor 
condition) so that they can be maintained. Routine and winter maintenance of the rehabilitated 
local roads would amount to GEL1,500–GEL4,000 per km yearly.  
24.  The Roads Department has no direct labor force: it contracts out all its maintenance and 
construction activities. The country is divided into 34 routine maintenance zones. Contractors 
bid against a bill of quantities drawn up by the department. The last round of bidding took place 
in 2007 and was for a period of 27 months. These contracts will expire in 2009 and will be rebid 
for a period of 12 months. Supervision and verification of quality and quantities were also 
contracted out to a private company but have now been brought into the department.

25.  The World Bank is supporting the Roads Department in improving the efficiency of road 
maintenance.  A  shift  from  contracted-out  maintenance  to  performance-based  maintenance 
contracts may produce further savings (up to 50%). A technical assistance project with the 
objective of developing a comprehensive framework for the introduction of performance-based 
maintenance contracts has been prepared. The international consultant, in collaboration with a 
small  Roads  Department  team,  will  apply  the  performance-based  maintenance  contracts 
framework to the preliminary assessment of a concession for the maintenance of the east–west 
highway and an area-wide contract for the rehabilitation and maintenance of 250–300 km of 
main  and  secondary  roads  centered  on  a  regional  office  of  the  Roads  Department. 
Performance-based maintenance of road projects undertaken under the multitranche financing 
facility will be standard.   
26.  The national contracting capacity in the road subsector comprises 13 large contractors 
with an annual turnover of more than GEL10 million, about 30 medium-sized contactors with an 
annual turnover of GEL5 million–GEL10 million, and more than 60 smaller contractors. 
G.  Road Safety 
27.  Road safety needs serious attention; there has been a sharp rise in traffic accidents, 
fatalities, and injuries. The current fatality rate is much higher in Georgia than in other European 
countries, and the economic and human losses have been significant. While traffic accidents 
have many causes, he inadequate road network is a factor. Curves and superelevation are 
inappropriately  designed  on  many  roads,  and  safety  furniture  is  lacking.  Other  causes  of 
accidents are weak enforcement of safety regulations, reckless driving, and the larger vehicle 
fleet. The Government should take remedial action to curb accidents. 
 
28.  The more than 6,000 accidents in 2008 that involved death or serious injury and killed 
867 people represented an increase of more than 18% over the 2007 figure (Table A2.6). The 
fatality rate relative to the vehicle fleet, at 12 per 10,000 vehicles in 2008, is high (removing 
scrapped vehicles from the fleet statistics would result in an even-higher rate)—and far exceeds 
the rate in other European countries.2 Both fatalities and serious injuries are on the rise. Road 
safety is therefore a serious social concern.  
 
29.  Georgia, as a member of the European Conference of Ministers of Transport (ECMT), is 
committed to reducing road deaths by 50% by 2012, compared with the 2000 figure. Whereas 
other countries had made good progress by 2004, with Western European countries reducing 
deaths by 5.2% per year and Central and Eastern European countries by 3.3% per year, road 
deaths in Georgia increased by 6.4% a year over the period. Besides emotional pain, traffic 
accidents have a direct impact on economic growth. A 1999 World Bank working paper, Road 
Safety in Individual ECA Countries,3 suggested that the socioeconomic cost of road accidents 
for Georgia was about 1.1% of GDP. Estimates made in 2007 indicate that the annual economic 
loss is now at least $100 million, 1.4% of GDP.

30.  Responsibility for road safety is spread among three ministries, and cooperation among 
the  three  appears  somewhat  sketchy.  The  interior  ministry,  through  the  patrol  police,  is 
responsible  for  attending  to  and  reporting  on  road  accidents,  as  well  as  enforcing  traffic 
regulations and laws. The road safety division of the Roads Department is responsible for 
ensuring that the road infrastructure is designed, constructed, and maintained safely. It carries 
out road safety improvements, sometimes at the request of the patrol police, and at other times 
after a manual analysis of the data collected by the police. The division is also responsible for 
installing and maintaining road signs and markings. The Transport Department of the Ministry of 
Economic Development was instrumental in producing a draft road safety strategy for Georgia. 
 
31.  Recognizing the growing problems, the Government has established a more-effective 
traffic policing capability, and will develop a multisector road safety strategy and a multisector 
road safety action plan based on the road safety study of Georgia conducted in 2008.  A road 
safety component was included in the World Bank Second East–West Highway Improvement 
Project,  to  strengthen  the  road  safety  division  of  the  Roads  Department,  to  implement  a 
program for hazardous locations along the east–west corridor, to design a new road accident 
database, and to develop traffic and safety engineering standards that can be applied to both 
urban and rural roads in Georgia. A further component proposed for the Third East–West 
Highway Improvement Project would involve the development of road safety audit manuals.  
H.  Vehicle Axle-Load Control 
32.  Georgia  has  regulations  that  limit  vehicle  axle  load  to  11.5  tons  (European  Union 
standard), but lower than the 13.0 tons in neighboring countries. But enforcement is weak, 
primarily because of limited institutional capacity and lack of vehicle weighing facilities along 
main roads. As a result, vehicle axle overloading is prevalent. On the other hand, if enforcement 
were high, there would dealing with transit traffic from countries with higher limits would be a 
problem. The countries in the Caucasus countries must coordinate and agree on a common 
limit. 
 
33.  Informal surveys conducted during the preparation of project 1 under the MFF indicated 
a problem with trucks exceeding the axle-load limit. Heavy vehicle weights are a primary cause 
of rapid pavement deterioration; therefore, vehicle axle-load control must be enforced to prevent 
such premature deterioration. 
 
34.  Vehicle weigh stations must be established along international roads, and overloaded 
vehicles should be required to redistribute or unload excess freight and also to collect reliable 
data on vehicle axle loads by installing permanent “weigh-in-motion” devices at key points. ADB 
is proposing to establish a vehicle weigh station on the Kobuleti bypass, under Tranche 1 of the 
MFF.

Appendix 2  37
I.  Road Transport Services 
35.  Georgia’s road freight industry is made up of private companies and is unregulated. 
Entry into the market is easy. It is difficult to judge the extent of market efficiency, but the freight 
rates of GEL0.20–GEL0.27 per ton-km for hauls of 100–500 km are consistent with the Highway 
Development and Management-4 estimate of operating costs, which suggests that profits are 
not excessive. 
36.  Intercity bus services are extensive and frequent. Although most routes are plied by both 
minibuses and larger buses, there is little to choose in terms of journey time, as all buses will 
stop to pick up passengers en route if they have room. Fares between bus stations (e.g., 
between Tbilisi and Batumi) are controlled by bus station operators, who take a cut from the 
fare. Bus station operators also appear to control capacity—a new entrant would find it difficult 
to operate a new service from an existing bus station. This control of both prices and capacity 
may be hindering the development of new services (e.g., express services).

ROAD SUBSECTOR ROAD MAP AND INVESTMENT PLAN 
 
A.  Sector Challenges 
 
1.  Like other sectors in Georgia, the road sector has been transformed from a centrally 
planned  to  a  market-oriented  system  since  independence.  The  sector  faces  four  major 
development challenges: (i) inadequate capacity of the road network including subregional 
corridors, (ii) insufficient road maintenance funding, (iii) unsatisfactory safety record, and (iv) 
limited institutional capacity to deliver an expanded road program. 
 
2.  Road  Network  Infrastructure.  Georgia’s  road  network  is  crucial  in  facilitating 
subregional transport and trade. The East–West Highway forms part of the Asian highway 
network1 connecting Georgia and Turkey to Azerbaijan and Central Asia. Georgia is a signatory 
to a number of international transport agreements and conventions. Continued development of 
an  integrated  and  efficient  road  network  will  facilitate  cross-border  and  transit  traffic  and 
contribute  to  subregional  cooperation  and  integration..The  existing  road  network  does  not 
adequately cater for the current needs of the economy and of the subregion and many roads 
remain  in  poor  condition.  Funding  for  secondary  and  local  road  maintenance  remains 
inadequate. A large part of the network deteriorated rapidly since 1990s and became non-
maintainable,  resulting  in  high  transport  costs  and  an  increase  in  traffic  accidents,  thus 
constituting an impediment to growth and poverty reduction. The road subsector needs to be 
developed to facilitate regional trade, investment and tourism. 
 
3.  Road  Maintenance  Funding.  Until  2004,  a  road  fund  existed,  financed  from  the 
proceeds of the fuel tax, the international transit tax and a road usage tax levied on individuals 
and enterprises. In 2004, the Government abolished special funds, including the road fund, and 
since then the sub-sector has been funded directly from the state budget and from donor funds. 
The proceeds of transport related taxes and fees are part of general revenue and are not 
earmarked  for  road  maintenance.  Under  the  proposed  Roads  Department  maintenance 
program for 2009-2013, an increase in annual funding from $110 million to $137 million is 
planned, with most of the increase earmarked for the periodic maintenance program. In 2007, 
the responsibility for local roads was transferred from Roads Department to 69 local authorities, 
as  part  of  broader  public  sector  reform  aimed  at  decentralizing  government  functions.  An 
estimated  GEL1,450  million  is  needed  to  rehabilitate  the  local  road  system  (90%  in  poor 
condition) and  bring it up to a maintainable condition. Rehabilitated local roads would then 
require  GEL1,500-4,000  per  km  annually  for  routine  and  winter  maintenance.  Despite  the 
growing  need  for  road  maintenance,  how  to  fund  it  remains  a  challenge.  Donors  closely 
coordinate to assist Roads Department in effectively cope with the challenge. For example, the 
World Bank is supporting Roads Department in improving the efficiency of its road maintenance 
activities  by  shifting  from  contracted-out  maintenance  to  performance-based  maintenance 
contracts. The Program will also support introduction of the performance-based maintenance 
contract and assist Roads Department in maintaining project roads through in such a way.  
 
4.  Road Safety. Road safety needs a serious attention; a sharp rise in the number of traffic 
accidents, fatalities, and injuries is apparent. The current fatality rate is much higher than that in 
European countries, causing economic and human losses. While there are many causes of 
traffic  accidents,  inadequacy  of  the  road  network  is  a  contributory  factor.  Curves  and

superelevation are inappropriately designed, and safety furniture is lacking on many roads. 
Other causes of accidents include weak enforcement of safety regulations, reckless driving, and 
increased vehicle fleet. Remedial action should be undertaken to stem accidents.  In 2008 there 
were over 6,000 accidents involving death or serious injury and 867 fatalities, a rise of over 18% 
on 2007. The fatality rate relative to the vehicle fleet at 12 per 10,000 vehicles in 2008 is high 
(even higher if scrapped vehicles are removed from the fleet statistics), higher than other 
European countries2. Both fatalities and serious injuries show an upward trend and road- safety 
becomes thus a serious social issue. Road safety should be improved through road network 
development and increased public safety awareness. The Government developed the National 
Traffic Safety Strategy in 2008 and makes an effort to strengthen the law enforcement and 
public  campaign  for  road  safety.  Aid  agencies  are  concerted  to  fill  the  resource  gap  for 
Government's effort. 
 
5.  Institutional  Capacity.  Despite  recent  progress  on  policy  and  institutional  reforms, 
institutional capacity in the road subsector remains limited. This is reflected by (i) lack of a legal 
and  regulatory  framework  for  managing  the  road  network;  (ii)  weak  enforcement  of  some 
existing regulations such as those relating to vehicle axle-load controls and road safety; (iii) lack 
of  experience  and  knowledge  about  private-public  partnership  in  road  construction  and 
maintenance; and (iv) limited staff experience in management of road projects, particularly in 
the  area  of  tunnel  and  bridge  engineering  and  environmental  and  resettlement  safeguard. 
Although the World Bank has continuously supported necessary institutional strengthening, 
further external assistance is needed to help R Roads Department in implementing the planned 
large-scale investment program. 
 
B.  Strategic Context 
 
6.  Georgia  serves  as  the  shortest  transit  link  between  Central  Asia  and  Europe,  the 
Russian Federation and Turkey. The physical location of Georgia ensures that it is a key 
transport link on the most direct route between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea and the 
Central Asian countries. It is also situated on the historic Silk Road, which is now realized as the 
Transport Corridor Europe–Caucasus–Asia route. Recognizing the strategic importance of a 
transit route connecting Central Asia and the Caspian Sea to Europe, the Government has 
accorded top priority rehabilitating and upgrading the East-West Highway to an international 
standard. In the long-term perspective, however, the development of subregional multi-road 
corridors will help exploit Georgia’s locational advantage as a transit hub. Efficiently functioning 
multi-road  corridors  will  diversify  the  connectivity  of  Georgia  to  neighboring  countries  and 
reduce the cost of subregional and international transport, benefiting both the local economy 
and the economy of the subregion, thereby stimulating the development of Euro-Asia trade 
links. The subregional multi-road-corridors also serve as principal domestic corridors linking the 
major  cities,  ports  and  tourist  centers,  and  their  development  enhances  economic  growth 
through more efficient passenger and freight transport.  
 
C.   Policy Framework  
 
7.  The Government transport sector policy is to develop the infrastructure and institutional 
setting of the sector to support market integration and to maximize the country’s potential as a 
transit  economy.  Government's  strategy  for  implementation  of  the  policy  includes:  (i)

establishment of the legal and regulatory framework for the private sector to participate in 
subregional  network  building  and  maintenance;  (ii)  capacity  development  of  road  sector 
institutions for efficient road management;  (iii) provision of sufficient resources, financial and 
technical, for local authorities to properly discharge their increased responsibility to manage 
road assets; and (iv) concessioning of construction and operation of main road network to  the 
private sector. The sector roadmap was developed in line with this policy framework. 
 
D.  Investment Plan and Sector Road Map 
 
8.  In 2008, the Government endorsed the Joint Needs Assessment (JNA) prepared by the 
United Nations together with the World Bank, ADB, the European Bank for Reconstruction and 
Development, the European Commission, the European Investment Bank, and the International 
Finance Corporation. JNA recognized the immediate need to upgrade Georgia's road networks 
and identified priority investment programs, noting that limited transport infrastructure added to 
the cost of doing business, deterred foreign investment, added time and costs to the transit 
corridor, and left large segments of the population out of mainstream economic activities. JNA 
also emphasized the necessity of subregional multi-road corridors to ensure provision of more 
efficient and secure transit routes. JNA set the basis for donors' assistance programming and 
cooperation. In 2009, Roads Department updated road transport infrastructure development 
needs reflected in JNA and identified the investment component that will construct, upgrade, 
and rehabilitate approximately 1,842 km of roads, comprising 372 km of main road network, 470 
km of alternative network, and 1,000 km of secondary and local network. The non-investment 
component  will  focus  on  priority  reforms,  including  the  development  of  regulations  and 
operational  procedures;  encouragement  of  private  sector  participation  in  construction  and 
maintenance; and capacity building for planning, monitoring, evaluation, and reporting. The 
overall investment reaches $3.0 billion over the 7-year period. Most of this will be financed from 
development aid agencies' assistance along with the Government’s budget. The Government 
has  also  sought  external  financing,  with  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  Millennium  Challenge 
Corporation (MCC), and Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) as the main sources.

SELECTION CRITERIA AND APPROVAL PROCESS FOR PROJECTS AND SUBPROJECTS 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will finance projects and subprojects that (i) are 
part  of  the  updated  road  transport  infrastructure  needs  brought  out  in  the  joint  needs 
assessment described in Schedule 1 of the framework financing agreement (FFA), (ii) adhere to 
the implementation arrangements set forth in Schedule 3 of the FFA, (iii) comply fully with the 
social dimensions and safeguard frameworks presented in Schedule 5 of the FFA, and (iv) meet 
the eligibility requirements set forth in this appendix. 
A.  Selection Criteria 
2.  To be financed under the multitranche financing facility (MFF), a proposed project or 
subproject must: 
 
(i)  construct, upgrade, or rehabilitate roads of high development priority, assessed 
for their contribution to the implementation of the road transport infrastructure 
needs reflected in the joint needs assessment and to the achievement of the 
objectives of the road subsector road map; 
(ii)  be in line with the approved feasibility assessment, meeting the engineering, 
financial,  economic,  environmental,  and  social  requirements  of  Georgia  and 
ADB; 
(iii)  be allocated counterpart funding sufficient to implement the project or subproject 
as scheduled, and maintain the project or subproject facilities upon completion; 
and 
(iv)  be granted government approvals and endorsements. 
B.  Approval Procedures 
3.  Approval procedures for projects or subprojects proposed for financing under the MFF 
will follow the required government review and approval processes as supplemented by the 
requirements of the Roads Department attached to Schedule 5 of the FFA. 
 
4.  For the project proposed for financing under tranche 1 of the MFF, all the necessary 
government approvals had been obtained as of the date of the FFA. 
 
5.  For  all  projects  intended  for  financing  under  subsequent  tranches  of  the  MFF,  the 
approval procedures will be as follows: 
 
(i)  The Roads Department will review the project or subproject proposals to confirm 
compliance with eligibility criteria, and then submit eligible projects or subproject 
proposals to the Ministry of Regional Development and Infrastructure (MORDI) 
for endorsement. 
(ii)  The Roads Department will prepare a periodic financing request (PFR) in a 
format agreed on with ADB for the financing of specific projects or subprojects, 
and submit the PFR to MORDI for review and approval. Upon interministerial 
consultation and approval of MORDI, the PFR will be submitted to ADB together 
with the eligible project or subproject proposals. 
(iii)  ADB, the Ministry of Finance, MORDI, and the Roads Department will maintain 
contact through periodic ADB review missions and quarterly progress reports, 
and in so doing will consult on PFRs before they are submitted to ADB.

46  Appendix 5 
 
6.  Subject to satisfactory compliance with the selection criteria and approval procedures, 
and in compliance with ADB’s relevant policies, ADB will approve the project or subproject 
proposals.

Appendix 6  47
 
ROAD DESIGN SUMMARY  
1.  Alignment. The proposed project roads bypass the cities of Kobuleti and Batumi, and 
coastal cities along the Black Sea in western Georgia (Adjara). The proposed bypass roads, 
48 kilometers  (km)  in  total  length  comprise  (i)  a  two-lane  road  east  of  Kobuleti  (28  km) 
traversing mostly plain areas, (ii) the existing road between Kobuleti and Batumi (6 km) widened 
from two to four lanes, and (iii) a two-lane road that will cut through densely populated hilly 
terrain east of Batumi (14 km). The new bypass roads are designed as two-lane roads, although 
land acquisition allows for future upgrading to four lanes with at least a 50–meter-wide reserve 
for the right-of way. 
 
2.  Geometric design standards. New Georgian design standards (April 2009) were used 
in  the  preliminary  design,  with  some  adjustments  approved  by  the  Roads  Department  as 
summarized below.  
 
(i)  The envelope for the tunnels was reduced by omitting the 2.5 m safety lane to 
reduce the cost. The revised envelope agrees with most international standards.  
(ii)  The lane width was reduced from 3.75 m to 3.5 m over the widening section 
(6 km) with 1 m shoulder because of restricted available land.  
(iii)  A slightly higher vertical crest and sag radii were adopted in flat terrain to reduce 
the bridge and tunnel lengths. They comply with most international standards.

3.  Pavement. An asphalt concrete pavement has been adopted to sustain the estimated

48  Appendix 6 
percentage of heavy vehicles in the traffic flow. The calculation of pavement layer thicknesses 
used the estimated cumulative axle loads in the design life and subsoil strength tests taken 
along sections of the alignment. The proposed pavement will vary along the road but will 
generally consist of 120 millimeters (mm) of asphalt concrete wearing and binding course, 230 
mm of crushed stone base, and 300 mm of granular subgrade. The proportions will be checked 
at the time of final design. 
  
4.  Structures and tunnels. There will be (i) 18 bridges (2,984 m in total length) and one 
tunnel (400 m) along the Kobuleti bypass; and (ii) 19 bridges (3,799 m) and 5 tunnels (1,510 m) 
along the Batumi bypass. Six bridges will be 500 meters or more in length.  
 
5.  The structures and tunnels conform to Georgian specifications except as mentioned in 
para. 2(i). Bridges are designed to carry 80-ton loads with 100 years’ flood return frequency. 
Culverts are designed to carry 50 years’ flood return frequency, and side drains, 20 years’ flood 
return frequency.  
 
6.  The project road is located in seismic zone IV (modified Mercalli scale); its design must 
therefore include anti-seismic measures to be included in the design of structures. Most bridges 
will be simple span reinforced concrete on piers and spread footings. Some bridges with longer 
spans will be pre-stressed T-girder superstructure. 
 
7.  The Georgian standard for two-way tunnels has a 2.5 m wide emergency lane on one 
side with a clear width of the 11.5 m road. This is an overly large tunnel cross-section compared 
with most international standards and would create difficulty in construction on poor ground, 
besides increasing construction time and cost. An internationally accepted cross-section, with 
two lanes 3.5 m wide, shoulders 1.25 m wide, and an inspection walkway 0.9 m wide on one 
side, is recommended. The tunnel is about 11 m wide, and about 7.5 m high. No tunnel 
ventilation is believed to be required because of the low traffic volume and the relatively short 
length of the tunnels. An illumination system is included in the tunnel design. Suitable facilities 
for traffic safety and emergency, based on the length of the tunnels and traffic volume, are also 
included in the design and in the cost estimates.  
 
8.  Materials  and  labor. Construction materials, such as boulders, stones, gravel, and 
sand, are locally available within a reasonable distance from the construction sites. Suitable 
sites have been identified and quantities estimated. A more detailed materials source study and 
analysis will be required for the final design. Other materials such as bitumen, steel, some 
cement, tunnel equipment, and spare parts will have to be imported. 
 
9.  Most skilled labor and all unskilled labor needed for the construction of roads and small 
to medium bridges, is available in Georgia, but skilled labor for the construction of tunnels and 
large bridges will need to be imported. 
 
10.  Quantity  estimates  are  based  on  the  preliminary  design  work.  These  include 
(i) earthworks estimated from the surveyed longitudinal profile and cross-sections; (ii) retaining 
structures and minor drainage; (iii) pavement works calculated on the basis of the thickness 
adopted in design and the pavement cross-section; (iv) bridgeworks estimated on the basis of 
the lengths of bridge spans, cross-sections, and soil type; (v) tunnel works based on the lengths 
of  the  tunnels,  cross-sections,  and  soil  types;  (vi)  interchanges  based  on  estimated  ramp 
lengths and widths and overpass spans; and (vii) ancillary works and road safety provisions 
based on the road and structure length, plans, and traffic volumes.

Appendix 6  49
 
11.  The unit rates for the major cost items are based on recent new-road and road-widening 
projects elsewhere in Georgia and adjusted for the first quarter of 2009. Rates for items not 
included in recent contracts are based on rates in other countries, adjusted for transport costs 
and taxes, etc., in Georgia. 
 
12.  Limitations  in  the  preliminary  design.  The  design  centerline  is  based  on  the 
preliminary design topographic survey and cross-sections taken from digitized 1:1,000 mapping. 
Optimization to the road geometry design will be necessary during detailed design after a 
detailed cross-section survey. This is expected to reduce some quantities, especially earthworks 
and bridge lengths. 
 
13.  Pavement  thicknesses  will  also  vary  during  detailed  design  and  construction.  It  is 
recommended that the California bearing ratios of subgrade be checked and that pavement 
thickness design be adjusted during detailed design and construction.  
 
14.  The geotechnical investigation, while covering most of the major structures, was limited 
to a tomography survey because of limited resources and time. In some cases, geological 
conditions were assumed on the basis of surveys at nearby sites. Additional geotechnical 
investigation will be required for each site during detailed design. The final design and quantities 
could change.

Appendix 11  61
 
ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF TRANCHE 1 AND 2 PROJECTS  
A.  General 
1.  The economic analysis assessed the construction of bypass roads on the Poti–Batumi–
Sarpi Road in the Autonomous Republic of Adjara. The projects comprise (i) the construction of 
a 34 kilometer (km) two- and four-lane bypass road from Kobuleti to Makhinjuari detouring 
Kobuleti, and (ii) the construction of a 14 km two-lane bypass road from Makhinjuari to Sarpi 
detouring Batumi. The projects will divert transit traffic away from the existing Poti–Batumi–Sarpi 
Road,  which  runs  through  the  urban  areas  of  Kobuleti  and  Batumi.  The  existing  road  is 
congested, accident-prone, and in poor condition. The economic analysis covered the period 
2010–2033, with the projects having their first full year of operation in 2014. The analysis was 
based on a comparison of with- and without-project cases and used economic prices in the first 
quarter  of  2009  unless  otherwise  indicated.  Various  alternatives  for  diverting  cross-border 
through traffic from the existing main roads in Kobuleti and Batumi were investigated. They 
included expanding the existing in-city roads and constructing new ones. Both alternatives were 
found to be economically and socially unviable because of their huge resettlement impact. For 
the bypass roads, after several alignments were compared in terms of their environmental and 
social impact, the proposed alignment was determined to be the least-cost option.  
B.  Existing Traffic and Forecast Traffic 
2.  The Roads Department conducts quarterly traffic counts (in April, July, and October) at 
three sites on the existing Poti–Batumi–Sarpi Road: the Choloki river crossing (Km 64), the 
Chakvi–Makinjauri tunnel (Km 95), and the Chorokhi river crossing (Km 115). Supplementary 
origin–destination surveys were conducted in May 2009 under the project preparatory technical 
assistance. The traffic counts and the origin–destination surveys had four major findings. First, 
the major traffic based on the number of vehicles is passenger traffic, and the share of car and 
bus traffic is more than 80% of the total traffic. Second, the slower or negative growth of traffic in 
2008 and 2009 clearly showed the effects of the recent global recession and the regional 
conflict. Third, the volume of traffic is strongly seasonal: car and minibus traffic is typically 30%–
50% higher in July than in April and October. Freight traffic, however, does not show such 
strong seasonality. Fourth, foreign registration plates on vehicles were noted, especially on 
articulated trucks, at all three sites, and bus traffic was observed to be large at the northern and 
southern sites. The average daily traffic in the base year (2009) was projected, on the basis of 
the surveys, and the traffic characteristics were noted. Table A11.1 summarizes the average 
daily traffic projection. 
 
3.  To forecast traffic on the project bypass roads, projections had to be prepared for 
(i) normal traffic, (ii) diverted traffic, and (iii) generated traffic. Normal traffic is the traffic that 
would arise on the existing Poti–Batumi–Sarpi Road without the projects. The forecast of normal 
traffic was based on projections of gross domestic product (GDP) growth and the estimated 
income elasticity of traffic demand.1 GDP growth was projected to recover gradually from 0% in 
2009 to 4% in 2013 and thereafter. Traffic demand elasticity of 1.2 for passenger traffic and 1.4 
for freight was used. Diverted traffic is traffic that prefers the project bypass roads to the existing 
Poti–Batumi–Sarpi  road.  More  freight  traffic  than  passenger  traffic  is  likely  to  divert.  It  is 
assumed that about 62% of freight traffic, and about 43% of total traffic, will divert to the bypass

C.  Economic Costs 
4.  The economic costs of the projects comprise (i) capital investment, including civil works, 
environmental  mitigation,  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  and  consulting  services  for 
construction supervision; and (ii) road maintenance. Costs related to taxes and duties and 
financing charges during implementation were excluded. The project costs were divided into 
tradable  and  non-tradable  components.  The  costs  of  non-tradable  components,  such  as 
unskilled labor and domestic materials, were converted into the world price numeraire through 
the  use  of  a  conversion  factor  of  0.97  and  the  official  exchange  rate  in  April  2009  of 
$1 = GEL1.67. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.7 was used to estimate the economic price of 
unskilled labor. Capital investment economic costs were estimated at $3.04 million per km for 
the Kobuleti bypass road and $7.38 million per km for the Batumi bypass road. The annual

Appendix 11  63
 
average route maintenance cost of the existing road between Kobuleti and Sarpi under the 
without-project  scenario  is  estimated  at  $2,000  per  km.  The  same  annual  average  route 
maintenance cost was assumed for the project bypass roads.  
 
5.  To attain the expected economic return on the capital investments, the Government’s 
ambitious road investment program needs to be supported by adequate institutional capacity. 
The Roads Department must be strengthened to fulfill its planning, monitoring, and executory 
roles  in  the  transformation  of  the  economy  into  a  market-oriented  system.  To  make  the 
proposed  investment  sustainable,  the  investment  program  will  support  the  development  of 
Roads Department capacity to plan, control axle load, design and build tunnels and bridges, 
manage contracts, and enforce compliance with environmental and resettlement safeguards. 
The investment program also has a road safety improvement component.  
D.  Economic Benefits 
6.  The quantified economic benefits of the projects are (i) savings in vehicle operating cost 
(VOC), (ii) savings in travel time, and (iii) a reduction in traffic accidents. The savings in travel 
time constitute the major part of the project benefits. Traffic diverting to the project bypass roads 
will benefit from higher speeds on a smoother riding surface with better vertical and horizontal 
alignment and less congestion. Traffic continuing to use the existing road will also benefit from a 
reduction in the volume of traffic and, hence, in congestion. All these changes will affect vehicle 
speeds and VOCs.

7.  Table A11.3 summarizes the typical economic benefits of savings in VOCs and travel 
time. The projects will allow more than 30% savings in travel time between Kobuleti and Sarpi 
for all types of vehicles. Values of time savings were derived on the basis of GDP per capita. 
Given the higher incomes in the project area because of the brisk business for tourism, GDP per 
capita in urban areas at purchasing power parity (about $4 per hour) was taken to be the 
working time of a car passenger. For bus passengers, whose share in total bus trips is small, $3 
per hour was assumed to be the working time. A nonworking trip was assigned 40% of the value 
of a working trip. As for goods traffic, 1 hour saved was estimated to be worth $0.30. The 
benefits of savings in VOCs per kilometer will be largest for large buses (19%), followed by 
articulated trucks. Cars are expected to save little. 
 
8.  Accident cost savings were also considered. From traffic accident data on the existing 
road, an accident rate of 1.30 per million vehicle-km on the existing road was estimated, with a 
severity rate per accident of 0.18 (for fatalities) and 1.84 (for injuries). For the project bypass 
roads, the accident rate and the severity rate per accident were based on experience in other 
projects and research results.  The assumption was that the accident rate would decrease to 
0.68, while severity per accident would increase to 0.24 (for fatalities) and 2.25 (for injuries). 
The cost of a fatality was calculated as the sum of forgone income (based on GDP per capita in 
2008 with a 12% discount rate for 20 years) and marginal emergency services and damage 
costs (assumed to be 20% of forgone income). The total value of a fatality was estimated to be 
$36,000,2 and a serious injury was valued at $11,500.3 The average accident cost was $34,500 
for the bypass roads and $27,600 for the existing road. The average number of accidents per 
year over the evaluation period was estimated to be 185 (including 23 fatal accidents and 
162 non-fatal accidents) with the projects and 301 (including 42 fatal and 259 non-fatal) without. 
The decrease in the number of accidents reduces the accident costs, though the average 
accident cost for the bypass roads is higher than that for the existing road.  
 
9.  The calculated benefits of generated traffic were half of the difference in unit road user 
costs with and without the projects multiplied  by the generated traffic volumes.  
E.  Economic Internal Rate of Return 
10.  An economic evaluation of the projects was undertaken, using the highway design and 
maintenance 4 (HDM-4) model. The projects were evaluated over 20 years; the first full year of 
benefits was assumed to be 2014. A residual value of 30% of capital costs was included in the 
final year of the evaluation period. The results are summarized in Table A11.4. They show that 
the projects are economically viable, with an estimated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) 
of 14.3% and an estimated net present value of $45.0 million.
