I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The project, under the Subregional Roads Corridors Development Investment Program, can be linked indirectly to the overall 
objective of the Government’s Development Agenda as reflected in the Basic Data and Directions 2008–2011 document and 
ADB’s interim operational strategy 2008–2009. Poverty reduction is one of the priorities of the Government. The main 
objectives are to reduce, over 2006–2015, overall poverty incidence from 31% to 15% and extreme poverty from 11% to 4%. 
These objectives can be achieved through infrastructure development, which removes economic growth bottlenecks. An 
important strategy in this regard is to develop transport infrastructure to strengthen market access and to realize Georgia’s 
transit economy potential more fully. ADB’s priorities in its interim operational strategy are based on such considerations as (i) 
alignment with the Government’s development agenda; (ii) selectivity in directing limited resources at a few priority areas; and 
(iii) complementarities  with  other  development  partners.  The  strategy  will  promote  sustainable  economic  growth,  with 
governance,  regional  cooperation,  and  environmental  protection  as  pervasive  themes,  by  (i)  improving  municipal 
infrastructure services within the evolving decentralization process, (ii) reducing road transportation constraints on economic 
activity, and (iii) upgrading and developing energy infrastructure. ADB’s operational engagement in this area will involve 
financing improvements in the highway network, resulting in lower transport costs, better road safety, and reduced traffic 
congestion and vehicle pollution. These are high-return, in-demand operations, and the Government has requested ADB 
assistance in this area to help address some of the remaining investment gaps. 
 
Georgia’s road network consists of 1,495 kilometers (km) of international, 5,446 km of state, and 13,386 km of local roads. 
The country has five main roads and highways, including the east–west highway connecting the ports of Poti and Batumi to 
the  Azerbaijan  border.  The  Government  has  been  encouraging  private  sector  participation  in  the  construction  and 
maintenance of highways. Given the country’s location, transport sector development is critical in reducing the logistics costs 
of economic activity and realizing Georgia’s full potential as a transit economy. The difficult terrain in some sections and 
congestion slow traffic, increase vehicle operating costs, and reduce road safety. Road maintenance costs are also high 
because of the terrain and weather conditions. About 10% of the main roads, 30% of the secondary roads, and 50% of the 
local roads are in poor condition and need rehabilitation. The Government has prioritized the improvement of the road 
network. The link between access to infrastructure services and poverty incidence has been well established in cross-country 
studies. For Georgia, rural–urban differences in access to infrastructure services go some way toward explaining the pattern 
of poverty incidence. Because of the generally poor condition of secondary and local roads, Georgia’s rural population, 
including ethnic minorities living in southern Georgia, face problems of isolation, with inadequate access to markets and to 
social services. In rehabilitating and upgrading secondary and local roads, it will be important to build in participatiory 
mechanisms involving local communities in the design and maintenance of the roads. Therefore, the project will have indirect 
linkage to the overall development goal. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General Intervention 
1. Key Issues  
Georgia ranks 97th out of 177 countries on the human development index of the United Nations Development Programme. It 
ranks higher than Azerbaijan (99th) but lower than Armenia (79th). Although growth will need to be more broad based to 
achieve  the  income  poverty  reduction  target,  the  policy  and  institutional  environment  for  achieving  the  Millennium 
Development Goals has improved in recent years with higher and more efficient spending in the social sectors. More than 
one-third of Georgia’s population is below the national poverty line and the poverty is relatively higher in the rural areas. 
Poverty incidence in Georgia is close to that in other countries in the South Caucasus. The incidence of poverty in Georgia is 
39.4% and the depth of poverty, 13.5%. The direct benefits of the investment program for the poor will be relatively small, but 
it will provide some direct employment opportunities during construction. The contribution of the investment program will be 
more indirect. The provision of transport services, including the construction and maintenance of transport infrastructure, will 
generate demand for labor (often unskilled labor) and provide income-earning opportunities for the poor. If a transport project 
generates jobs for the poor who are otherwise unemployed or underemployed, it contributes indirectly to poverty reduction. 
The construction aspect of transport sector development is often seen to be just as important as the service aspect in 
promoting economic growth. The process of poverty reduction is rooted in a broad range of socioeconomic activities to which 
transport services provide intermediate inputs. The proposed project will have both short-term and long-term positive impact.

Appendix 12  69
 
The short-term positive impact will include access to markets for agricultural produce, availability of temporary unskilled jobs 
for villagers, and opportunity to provide food and restaurant services for construction workers. The long-term positive impact, 
on the other hand, will include access to long-distance transport services across the border, access to long-distance markets 
(buying and selling through regional trade), easier access to health facilities and medical treatment, increased access to 
agricultural extension services, increased access to education, increased opportunity for the development of tourism, and 
diversification of income sources.  
 
2. Design Features.  
No direct impact on poverty is envisaged to occur as a result of the implementation of this project. Nonetheless, the project 
will have an indirect impact on Georgia as a whole. 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
Findings of Social Analysis  
The investment program will have a positive socioeconomic impact on Georgia. A sample socioeconomic survey of 200 
households in 20 villages in the project area was carried out. Of the households that were surveyed, 70% are from villages 
and 30% from urban areas. Among the heads of households, about 83% are males and 17% are females. Most of the 
sampled households (about 98%) are of Georgian ethnicity. The sex ratio in the project area favors the females (1,004 
females to 1,000 males). The average family has 5.04 members. Literacy in the project area is almost 100%. However, the 
majority of the residents (about 59%) have not gone beyond a secondary education and only about 16% have a university 
education (same for both genders). Agriculture is the primary economic activity among 81% of the households, followed by 
government services (33.17%) and business and trading (8.91%). Out of 39 households with secondary economic activities, 
nearly 9% practice agriculture and 3.47% are employed with the government or have their own business. Among household 
members 15 years old and above, 70% are unemployed (65% males and 75% females). About 6.43% of the households are 
landless. Almost all the land is cultivable and unirrigated. On the other hand, a household owns 0.022 hectare of residential 
land on average. The total annual average income per family is GEL6,024 and the median annual income is GEL4,660. 
Television sets (97.5%), LPG gas stoves (78.2%), and refrigerators are common household assets among the sampled 
households. Large animals like cows, bulls, buffaloes are owned by 57% of the households and poultry is owned by nearly 
23% of the households. About 40% of the households surveyed reported having loans, and most of these were bank loans. 
Most of the structures and buildings are double-storied, and 88% are cemented structures. Among the households, 98.5% are 
connected to central power supply. The average number of rooms available in the sampled households is 6.11. Only 2.5% of 
households reported having connection to the natural gas pipeline. Piped water supply is the common source of water for half 
of the households. About 48.51% have flush toilets and the rest have latrines. Wood is used as fuel for heating in 94% of the 
households. About 89% of the sampled households have access to health centers. The average distance of the health 
centers from their houses is 3.1 km; for 8.23%, the health center is within 1 km from their houses. Ninety-five percent have 
access to schools for their children. About 94.55% of households have houses with immediate access to roads. For 86% of 
the households, the immediate approach road is the village road, and for 10% it is the highway. The survey and the analysis 
indicated that almost 52% of the households in the project area are living below the poverty line. 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1. Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation. 
Consultations were carried out with all the stakeholders during program preparation. As an integral part of the safeguards 
planning, affected communities and affected persons were directly and fully involved in the project preparation and during the 
design.  All  stakeholders  were  informed  about  the  project,  and  the  stream  of  information  will  continue  during  the 
implementation of the project. Extensive consultation events were arranged at various stages of social and resettlement 
project  preparation—alternative-alignment  feasibility  study,  cadastral  survey  of  affected  lands,  land  census  survey, 
socioeconomic survey, and targeted consultation meetings with affected people and local stakeholder organizations and 
individuals. Consultations were also held at various levels of government offices such as the Department of Roads (including 
its resettlement division), the National Agency for Public Registry under the Ministry of Justice, local governments at the rayon 
(district  municipality)  level,  gamgebeli  (governors),  property  recognition  committees  in  the  rayon,  and  sacrebulo 
(representative local autonomous bodies). Community consultations were held through focus group discussions at various 
locations, especially at 20 villages in April 2009. A total of 210 men and women participated. The consultations will continue 
throughout the project cycle.

C.  Gender and Development 
1.  Key Issues.  
The investment program will pay particular attention to women to ensure that they receive rightful compensation for their 
activities and that women who are de facto household heads are clearly listed as beneficiaries of compensation and 
rehabilitation proceedings under the loan. Women will also participate in the consultation process to determine and negotiate 
compensation entitlements and implement the land acquisition and resettlement plan (LARP). Special attention will be given 
to the impact of resettlement on women and other vulnerable groups during the monitoring and evaluation of the LARP. The 
investment program will have a positive impact on gender, because the civil works contracts will include provisions to 
encourage the employment of women during implementation, and women will be urged to participate in the monitoring of 
program impact. No particular issue is expected to arise from the implementation of the project. Nonetheless, additional 
compensation will be given to households headed by women, which are considered to be more vulnerable.

SUMMARY LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT PLAN FOR TRANCHE 1 PROJECT   
A.  Introduction and Project Background 
1.  This is the summary land acquisition and resettlement plan (LARP) for project 1 under 
the Road Corridor Investment Program. This was prepared by the Roads Department of the 
Ministry of Regional Development and Infrastructure (MORDI) of Georgia. Project 1 comprises 
the construction of the Kobuleti bypass (28 kilometers [km]) and 6 km of road widening. The 
total length of the project road under project 1 is 34 km. The project road will fall within the 
jurisdiction of Adjara and Guria province. Sufficient consideration has been given during the 
inception and feasibility phases of project preparation to minimize the adverse impact on land 
acquisition and resettlement through the best engineering solution. The assessment of losses 
and land acquisition is based on the preliminary design, which was part of the feasibility study. If 
required, the LARP will need to be updated to conform to the detailed engineering design. 
However, the preliminary design was done to the extent possible, and will not significantly 
change  during  detailed  design  as  far  as  the  land  requirement  land  is  concerned.  The 
assessment is based on a right-of-way of 50 meters (m) (25 m on either side of the central line). 
The aims and objectives of the LARP are to mitigate all such unavoidable negative impact 
caused by the investment program, to resettle the displaced persons, and to restore their 
livelihoods.  The  LARP  also  provides  guidelines  for  the  implementation  of  land  acquisition 
through proper compensation and assistance according to the policies of ADB and the relevant 
Georgian laws and regulations. 
 
2.  The initiation of civil works on the project 1 components needs to fulfill the conditionality 
such as (i) approval of this LARP by ADB, (ii) full disclosure of this LARP to the affected 
persons; (iii) updating of the LARP to conform to the detailed engineering design, and disclosure 
of the updated LARP, and (iv) full implementation of the compensation program described in 
this LARP including the full delivery of compensation to the affected persons.  
B.  Impact on Land Acquisition And Resettlement 
3.  Project 1 components will entail significant land acquisition and resettlement. A detailed 
impact assessment including the census survey has been carried out to assess the impact of 
the project on land acquisition and resettlement. About 740 land parcels will be affected and the 
total  agricultural  land  required  for  land  acquisition  is  160.9  ha,  out  of  which  134.8  ha  is 
agricultural and 26.1 ha is nonagricultural or pasture land. Additionally, 2.39 ha of residential 
and commercial land will be affected. The total number of affected structures and buildings is 
154,  out  of  which  123  are  residential  structures,  18  are  commercial  structures,  and  the 
remaining  13  are  community  property  resources,  which  includes  schools  and  government 
buildings. About 2,020 fruit-bearing trees and 200 timber trees will be affected because of the 
project. The total number of households losing business is 18, whereas 141 households are 
eligible for relocation allowances. The total number of affected vulnerable households is 332, 
which includes households headed by women and households below the poverty line. The total 
number of affected households is 881; of this total 200 are legal titleholders, 119 are non-
titleholders, and 562 households belong to the category of those who can be legalized. The total 
number of affected persons is estimated to be 4,440. The impact on land acquisition and 
resettlement is summarized in Table A13.1.

C.  Indigenous Peoples and Vulnerable Groups including Women 
4.  The investment program is not expected to have any impact on indigenous peoples. An 
assessment  of  impact  on  indigenous  peoples  was  made  according  to  ADB’s  Policy  on 
Indigenous Peoples (1998). The investment program will primarily affect Georgian people, who 
compose almost 93% of the population. Other ethnic groups, insignificant in number, are also 
present in the program area. These groups are mostly Armenian, Azeri, and Russian. They 
have been fully integrated into institutional, cultural, and economic processes in the country, and 
do not display sufficient features to be classified as indigenous peoples according to ADB’s 
definition.  Therefore,  the  investment  program  is  category  C.  Special  attention  is  given  to 
identifying and addressing the needs of disadvantaged groups such as the landless, the poor, 
households headed by women, the elderly, and the disabled, through measures included in the 
LARP to try and improve their livelihoods (over and above cash compensation and restoration). 
Women have important economic roles in project areas and engage in a very wide range of 
income-generating activities in the agricultural and marketing sector. The investment program 
will pay particular attention to women to ensure that they receive rightful compensation for their 
activities and that women who are de facto household heads are clearly listed as beneficiaries 
of compensation and rehabilitation proceedings under the loan.  
 
D.  Resettlement Policy, Principles, and Legal Framework 
 
5.  The  legal  framework  is  based  on  both  Georgian  laws  and  ADB’s  Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy (1995). In Georgia, several items of legislation regulate the acquisition by

74  Appendix 13 
the State of privately owned land to meet public needs such as the construction of public roads: 
(i) the Constitution of Georgia, 24 August 1995; (ii) the Civil Code of Georgia, 26 June 1997; 
(iii) the Law of Georgia on Privatization of State-Owned Agricultural Land, 8 July 2005; (iv) the 
Law of Georgia on Ownership Rights to Agricultural Land, 22 March 1996; (v) the Law of 
Georgia on Registration Ownership Rights to Immovable Property, 28 December 2005; (vi) the 
Law of Georgia on the Rules for Expropriation of Ownership for Necessary Public Need, 23 July 
1999; and (vii) the Civil Procedural Code of Georgia, 14 November 1997. Core involuntary 
resettlement principles, based on the Georgian laws on land acquisition and ADB’s Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy (1995), have been adopted for the project 1 components, as follows: 
 
(i)  land  acquisition  and  other  involuntary  resettlement  impact  will  be  avoided  or 
minimized through all viable alternative project designs; 
(ii)  where such impact is unavoidable, a time-bound LARP will be prepared and affected 
persons will be assisted in improving or at least regaining their standard of living 
before the investment program;  
(iii)  affected persons will be consulted on compensation, resettlement information will be 
disclosed to them, and they will be encouraged to participate in the planning and 
implementation of subprojects;  
(iv)  vulnerable and severely affected affected persons will be given special assistance;  
(v)  non-titled affected persons (e.g., informal dwellers or squatters, or affected persons 
without  registration  details)  will  receive  a  livelihood  allowance  in  lieu  of  land 
compensation and will be fully compensated for losses other than land; 
(vi)  affected persons who can be legalized will be legalized and fully compensated for 
land losses;  
(vii)  income will be restored and rehabilitated; 
(viii)  the LARP will be disclosed to the affected persons in the local language; 
(ix)  compensation, resettlement assistance, and rehabilitation measures will be fully 
provided  before  the  contractor  takes  over  the  land  and  before  the  start  of 
construction work on a particular package; and  
(x)  appropriate grievance redresses mechanisms will be established to solve the 
grievances of affected persons, if any. 
E.  Compensation Eligibility and Entitlements  
6.  Land acquisition and resettlement tasks under project 1 will be implemented according 
to compensation eligibility and entitlements in line with both Georgian laws and regulations and 
ADB’s policy. Affected persons entitled to compensation or at least rehabilitation provisions under 
project 1 are (i) all affected persons losing land covered by legal title or traditional land rights 
who  can  be  legalized  or  are  without  legal  status;  (ii)  tenants  and  sharecroppers,  whether 
registered or not; (iii) owners of buildings, crops, plants, or other objects attached to the land; 
and (iv) affected persons losing business, income, and salaries. Compensation eligibility is 
limited by a cutoff date on the day of the beginning of the affected person census and detailed 
measurement survey, which is June 2009. A summary entitlement matrix is in Table A13.2.

76  Appendix 13 
F.  Institutional Arrangements 
7.  ADB will be the funding agency of the MFF. MORDI will be the executing agency and the 
Roads Department will be the implementing agency entrusted with the lead responsibility for 
road construction, as well as the implementation of this LARP. This responsibillity includes the 
preparation, implementation, and financing of all land acquisition and resettlement tasks and 
cross-agency coordination. Roads Department will exercise its functions through its existing 
resettlement division (DRD), which will be responsible for the general management of the 
planning and implementation of all land acquisition and resettlement tasks. Roads Department 
with the assistance of the construction supervision consultants will develop and implement them 
based on the policy and procedures set out in the LARP. In addition to the Roads Department, a 
number of other government departments and private agents will play an instrumental role in the 
design, construction, and operation of the project. Pursuant to the active legislation, the Ministry 
of Natural Resources and Environmental Protection is responsible for environmental issues. 
The Ministry of Justice is responsible for legal matters regarding land ownership, and the 
National Agency of Public Registry within the Ministry of Justice is in charge of the registration 
of land ownership and its transfer through purchase agreement from landowners to the Roads 
Department. Local government at the rayon (district municipality) and village levels will also be 
involved. To allow the effective execution of all land acquisition and resettlement related tasks 
some expansion of the capacity for land acquisition and resettlement (currently weak) at DRD 
and/or Roads Department will be needed and capacity building training will be provided. 
G.  Complaints and Grievance 
8.  A grievance mechanism will be made available to allow affected persons to appeal any 
unfavorable  decision,  practice,  or  activity  arising  from  land  or  other  asset  compensation. 
Affected persons will be fully informed of their rights and of the procedures for addressing 
complaints, whether verbally or in writing, during consultation and survey, and at the time of 
compensation.  First,  complaints  resolution  will  be  attempted  at  the  village  level  with  the 
involvement  of  village  authorities,  at  the  rayon  level,  and  through  the  land  aquisition  and 
resettlement team at the sacrebulo (representative local autonomous bodies) level. Second, if 
the grievance is not solved at the sacrebulo level, then the affected person will lodge a written 
complaint at the regional level Roads Department. If, after the regional level Roads Department 
intervention, no solution has been reached, a grievance can be directly lodged to DRD and/or 
Roads  Department.  The  affected  person  must  lodge  the  complaint  within  2  weeks  after 
receiving a response to the original complaint from the regional Roads Department and must 
produce documents supporting his or her claim. Third, the DRD and/or Roads Department at 
the central level will provide a response within 2 weeks of the time the complaint is registered. 
The DRD and/or Roads Department decision must be in compliance with the provisions of this 
land acquisition and resettlement framework. Fourth, if the grievance redress system fails to 
satisfy the affected person, he or she may pursue further action by submitting the case to the 
appropriate court of law (rayon court).  
H.  Public Consultation, Participation, and Disclosure  
9.  Extensive consultations were conducted at various stages of social and resettlement 
project preparation—alternative alignment feasibility study, cadastral survey of affected lands, 
land census survey, socioeconomic survey, and targeted consultation meetings with affected 
people and local stakeholder organizations and individuals. Consultations were also held at 
various office levels such as Roads Department including DRD, National Agency for Public

Appendix 13  77
 
Registry under the Ministry of Justice, Local Government at rayon level, gamgebeli (governors), 
the property recognition committee in the rayon and sacrebulo. Community consultations were 
held through focus group discussions at various locations, especially at 20 villages in April 2009, 
at which involved 210 men and women participated. The consultations will continue throughout 
the project cycle. A resettlement information leaflet containing information on compensation, 
entitlement, and resettlement management adopted for the project will be made available in the 
local language(s) and distributed to affected persons. Each affected person will be provided 
information regarding specific entitlements. Information sharing on LAR entitlement was shared 
at the village level through consultation and through formal public consultation during the public 
hearing under the environmental impact assessment in the month of June 2009. This summary 
LARP will be translated into the local language (Georgian) and disclosed to affected persons at 
the local level. A copy of the LARP will be available at the  Roads Department. The same will be 
available for the affected persons as and when asked for. A copy of the LARP will be disclosed 
on ADB’s website. 
I.  Resettlement Budget, Financing and Implementation Schedule 
10.  The resettlement cost estimate for project 1 components includes eligible compensation, 
resettlement assistance, and support for the costs of resettlement plan implementation. All 
LARP preparation and implementation costs, including the cost of compensation and land 
acquisition and resettlement administration, will be considered an integral part of project cost 
and will be contributed as a counterpart fund by the Georgia Government, in particular Roads 
Department. The total estimated cost for the LARP for project 1 is about $5.90 million. Roads 
Department is responsible for the timely allocation of the funds needed to implement the LARP. 
As  per  the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  fund  flow,  the  budget  for  compensation  and 
rehabilitation will be directly disbursed by Roads Department to the affected person. All land 
acquisition, resettlement, and compensation will be completed before the start of civil works.  
J.  Monitoring and Evaluation  
11.  Land acquisition and resettlement tasks under the project will be monitored. Monitoring 
will be the responsibility of Roads Department. Internal monitoring will be carried out routinely 
by DRD and/or Roads Department. The results will be communicated to ADB through the 
quarterly project implementation reports. External monitoring will be carried out twice a year, 
and its results communicated to DRD and/or Roads Department and ADB through semiannual 
reports. The Roads Department will carry out a post-implementation evaluation of the LARP 
about a year after the completion of its implementation. Roads Department may need external 
help in monitoring the first-tranche LARP implementation activities.
